metadata.title: Australian Government Information Security Manual 2021-12 - OSCAL Catalog

control.title: Providing cyber security leadership and guidance

part.name: SecurityControl0714
part.p: A CISO is appointed to provide cyber security leadership and guidance for their organisation.

part.name: SecurityControl1478
part.p: The CISO oversees their organisation’s cyber security program and ensures their organisation’s compliance with cyber security policy, standards, regulations and legislation.

part.name: SecurityControl1617
part.p: The CISO regularly reviews and updates their organisation’s cyber security program to ensure its relevance in addressing cyber threats and harnessing business and cyber security opportunities.

part.name: SecurityControl0724
part.p: The CISO implements cyber security measurement metrics and key performance indicators for their organisation.

part.name: SecurityControl0725
part.p: The CISO coordinates cyber security and business alignment through a cyber security steering committee or advisory board, comprising of key cyber security and business executives, which meets formally and on a regular basis.

part.name: SecurityControl0726
part.p: The CISO coordinates security risk management activities between cyber security and business teams.

part.name: SecurityControl0718
part.p: The CISO reports directly to their organisation’s senior executive and/or Board on cyber security matters.

part.name: SecurityControl0733
part.p: The CISO is fully aware of all cyber security incidents within their organisation.

part.name: SecurityControl1618
part.p: The CISO oversees their organisation’s response to cyber security incidents.

control.title: Contributing to business continuity and disaster recovery planning

part.name: SecurityControl0734
part.p: The CISO contributes to the development and maintenance of business continuity and disaster recovery plans for their organisation to ensure that business-critical services are supported appropriately in the event of a disaster.

control.title: Developing a cyber security communications strategy

part.name: SecurityControl0720
part.p: The CISO develops and maintains a cyber security communications strategy for their organisation.

control.title: Working with suppliers and service providers

part.name: SecurityControl0731
part.p: The CISO oversees cyber supply chain risk management activities for their organisation.

control.title: Receiving and managing a dedicated cyber security budget

part.name: SecurityControl0732
part.p: The CISO receives and manages a dedicated cyber security budget for their organisation.

part.name: SecurityControl0717
part.p: The CISO oversees the management of cyber security personnel within their organisation.

part.name: SecurityControl0735
part.p: The CISO oversees the development and operation of their organisation’s cyber security awareness training program.

part.name: SecurityControl1071
part.p: Each system has a designated system owner.

part.name: SecurityControl1525
part.p: System owners register each system with its authorising officer.

part.name: SecurityControl1633
part.p: System owners determine the type, value and security objectives for each system based on an assessment of the impact if it were to be compromised.

part.name: SecurityControl1634
part.p: System owners select security controls for each system and tailor them to achieve desired security objectives.

part.name: SecurityControl1635
part.p: System owners implement security controls for each system and its operating environment.

part.name: SecurityControl1636
part.p: System owners ensure security controls for each system and its operating environment are assessed to determine if they have been implemented correctly and are operating as intended.

part.name: SecurityControl0027
part.p: System owners obtain authorisation to operate each system from its authorising officer based on the acceptance of the security risks associated with its operation.

part.name: SecurityControl1526
part.p: System owners monitor each system, and associated cyber threats, security risks and security controls, on an ongoing basis.

control.title: Annual reporting of system security status

part.name: SecurityControl1587
part.p: System owners report the security status of each system to its authorising officer at least annually.

part.name: SecurityControl0576
part.p: An intrusion detection and prevention policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1625
part.p: A trusted insider program is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1626
part.p: Legal advice is sought regarding the development and implementation of a trusted insider program.

control.title: Access to sufficient data sources and tools

part.name: SecurityControl0120
part.p: Cyber security personnel have access to sufficient data sources and tools to ensure that systems can be monitored for key indicators of compromise.

part.name: SecurityControl0125
part.p: A cyber security incident register is maintained that covers the following: • the date the cyber security incident occurred • the date the cyber security incident was discovered • a description of the cyber security incident • any actions taken in response to the cyber security incident • to whom the cyber security incident was reported.

part.name: SecurityControl0133
part.p: When a data spill occurs, data owners are advised and access to the data is restricted.

control.title: Handling and containing malicious code infections

part.name: SecurityControl0917
part.p: When malicious code is detected, the following steps are taken to handle the infection: • the infected systems are isolated • all previously connected media used in the period leading up to the infection are scanned for signs of infection and isolated if necessary • antivirus software is used to remove the infection from infected systems and media • if the infection cannot be reliably removed, systems are restored from a known good backup or rebuilt.

part.name: SecurityControl0137
part.p: Legal advice is sought before allowing intrusion activity to continue on a system for the purpose of collecting further data or evidence.

part.name: SecurityControl1609
part.p: System owners are consulted before allowing intrusion activity to continue on a system for the purpose of collecting further data or evidence.

part.name: SecurityControl1731
part.p: Planning and coordination of intrusion remediation activities are conducted on a separate system to that which has been compromised.

part.name: SecurityControl1732
part.p: To the extent possible, all intrusion remediation activities are conducted in a coordinated manner during the same planned outage.

part.name: SecurityControl1213
part.p: Following intrusion remediation activities, full network traffic is captured for at least seven days and analysed to determine whether the adversary has been successfully removed from the system.

part.name: SecurityControl0138
part.p: The integrity of evidence gathered during an investigation is maintained by investigators: • recording all of their actions • creating checksums for all evidence • copying evidence onto media for archiving • maintaining a proper chain of custody.

part.name: SecurityControl0123
part.p: Cyber security incidents are reported to an organisation’s CISO, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

part.name: SecurityControl0141
part.p: Service providers report cyber security incidents to their customer’s CISO, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

part.name: SecurityControl1433
part.p: Service providers and their customers maintain 24x7 contact details for each other, including additional out-of-band contact details for when normal communication channels fail, in order to report cyber security incidents.

control.title: Reporting cyber security incidents to the ACSC

part.name: SecurityControl0140
part.p: Cyber security incidents are reported to the ACSC.

part.name: SecurityControl1631
part.p: Components and services relevant to the security of systems are identified and understood.

part.name: SecurityControl1452
part.p: Before obtaining components and services relevant to the security of systems, a review of suppliers and service providers (including their country of origin) is performed to assess the potential increase to systems’ security risk profile, including by identifying those that are high risk.

part.name: SecurityControl1567
part.p: Suppliers and service providers identified as high risk are not used.

part.name: SecurityControl1568
part.p: Components and services relevant to the security of systems are chosen from suppliers and service providers that have made a commitment to secure-by-design practices.

part.name: SecurityControl1632
part.p: Components and services relevant to the security of systems are chosen from suppliers and service providers that have a strong track record of transparency and maintaining the security of their own systems, services and cyber supply chains.

part.name: SecurityControl1569
part.p: A shared responsibility model is created, documented and shared between suppliers, service providers and their customers in order to articulate the security responsibilities of each party.

part.name: SecurityControl1637
part.p: An outsourced cloud services register is maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl1638
part.p: An outsourced cloud services register contains the following for each outsourced cloud service: • cloud service provider’s name • cloud service’s name • purpose for using the cloud service • sensitivity or classification of data involved • due date for the next security assessment of the cloud service • point of contact for users of the cloud service • point of contact for the cloud service provider.

part.name: SecurityControl1570
part.p: Cloud service providers and their cloud services undergo a security assessment by an IRAP assessor at least every 24 months.

part.name: SecurityControl1529
part.p: Only community or private clouds are used for outsourced SECRET and TOP SECRET cloud services.

part.name: SecurityControl1395
part.p: Service providers provide an appropriate level of protection for any data entrusted to them or their services.

part.name: SecurityControl0072
part.p: Security requirements associated with the confidentiality, integrity and availability of data entrusted to a service provider are documented in contractual arrangements.

part.name: SecurityControl1571
part.p: The right to audit security controls associated with the protection of data and services is specified in contractual arrangements.

part.name: SecurityControl1451
part.p: Types of data and its ownership is documented in contractual arrangements.

part.name: SecurityControl1572
part.p: The regions or availability zones where data will be processed, stored and communicated is documented in contractual arrangements.

part.name: SecurityControl1573
part.p: Access to all logs relating to an organisation’s data and services are specified in contractual arrangements.

part.name: SecurityControl1574
part.p: Data entrusted to a service provider is stored in a portable manner that allows organisations to perform backups, service migration or service decommissioning without any loss of data.

part.name: SecurityControl1575
part.p: A minimum notification period of one month for the cessation of any services by a service provider is documented in contractual arrangements.

control.title: Access to systems and data by service providers

part.name: SecurityControl1073
part.p: An organisation’s systems and data are not accessed or administered by a service provider unless a contractual arrangement exists between the organisation and the service provider to do so.

control.title: Access to systems and data by service providers

part.name: SecurityControl1576
part.p: If an organisation’s systems or data are accessed or administered by a service provider in an unauthorised manner, organisations are immediately notified.

group.title: Development and maintenance of security documentation

part.name: SecurityControl0039
part.p: A cyber security strategy is developed and implemented for the organisation.

part.name: SecurityControl0047
part.p: Organisational-level security documentation is approved by the Chief Information Security Officer while system-specific security documentation is approved by the system’s authorising officer.

part.name: SecurityControl0888
part.p: Security documentation is reviewed at least annually and includes a ‘current as at [date]’ or equivalent statement.

part.name: SecurityControl1602
part.p: Security documentation, including notification of subsequent changes, is communicated to all stakeholders.

part.name: SecurityControl0041
part.p: Systems have a system security plan that includes a description of the system and an annex that covers both applicable security controls from this document and any additional security controls that have been identified.

part.name: SecurityControl0043
part.p: Systems have an incident response plan that covers the following: • guidelines on what constitutes a cyber security incident • the types of cyber security incidents likely to be encountered and the expected response to each type • how to report cyber security incidents, internally to the organisation and externally to relevant authorities • other parties which need to be informed in the event of a cyber security incident • the authority, or authorities, responsible for investigating and responding to cyber security incidents • the criteria by which an investigation of a cyber security incident would be requested from a law enforcement agency, the Australian Cyber Security Centre or other relevant authority • the steps necessary to ensure the integrity of evidence relating to a cyber security incident • system contingency measures or a reference to such details if they are located in a separate document.

part.name: SecurityControl1163
part.p: Systems have a continuous monitoring plan that includes: • conducting vulnerability scans for systems at least monthly • conducting vulnerability assessments or penetration tests for systems at least annually • analysing identified security vulnerabilities to determine their potential impact • using a risk-based approach to prioritise the implementation of mitigations based on effectiveness and cost.

part.name: SecurityControl1563
part.p: At the conclusion of a security assessment for a system, a security assessment report is produced by the assessor and covers: • the scope of the security assessment • the system’s strengths and weaknesses • security risks associated with the operation of the system • the effectiveness of the implementation of security controls • any recommended remediation actions.

part.name: SecurityControl1564
part.p: At the conclusion of a security assessment for a system, a plan of action and milestones is produced by the system owner.

part.name: SecurityControl0810
part.p: Systems are secured in facilities that meet the requirements for a security zone suitable for their sensitivity or classification.

control.title: Physical access to servers, network devices and cryptographic equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1053
part.p: Servers, network devices and cryptographic equipment are secured in server rooms or communications rooms that meet the requirements for a security zone suitable for their sensitivity or classification.

control.title: Physical access to servers, network devices and cryptographic equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1530
part.p: Servers, network devices and cryptographic equipment are secured in security containers or secure rooms suitable for their sensitivity or classification taking into account the combination of security zones they reside in.

control.title: Physical access to servers, network devices and cryptographic equipment

part.name: SecurityControl0813
part.p: Server rooms, communications rooms, security containers and secure rooms are not left in unsecured states.

control.title: Physical access to servers, network devices and cryptographic equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1074
part.p: Keys or equivalent access mechanisms to server rooms, communications rooms, security containers and secure rooms are appropriately controlled.

control.title: Physical access to network devices in public areas

part.name: SecurityControl1296
part.p: Physical security controls are implemented to protect network devices in public areas from physical damage or unauthorised access.

control.title: Bringing Radio Frequency and infrared devices into facilities

part.name: SecurityControl1543
part.p: An authorised RF and IR device register is maintained and regularly audited for SECRET and TOP SECRET areas.

control.title: Bringing Radio Frequency and infrared devices into facilities

part.name: SecurityControl0225
part.p: Unauthorised RF and IR devices are not brought into SECRET and TOP SECRET areas.

control.title: Bringing Radio Frequency and infrared devices into facilities

part.name: SecurityControl0829
part.p: Security measures are used to detect and respond to unauthorised RF devices in SECRET and TOP SECRET areas.

part.name: SecurityControl0164
part.p: Unauthorised people are prevented from observing systems, in particular workstation displays and keyboards, within facilities.

part.name: SecurityControl0161
part.p: ICT equipment and media are secured when not in use.

part.name: SecurityControl0252
part.p: Cyber security awareness training is undertaken annually by all personnel and covers: • the purpose of the cyber security awareness training • security appointments and contacts within the organisation • authorised use of systems and their resources • protection of systems and their resources • reporting of cyber security incidents and suspected compromises of systems and their resources.

part.name: SecurityControl1565
part.p: Tailored privileged user training is undertaken annually by all privileged users.

control.title: Reporting suspicious contact via online services

part.name: SecurityControl0817
part.p: Personnel are advised of what suspicious contact via online services is and how to report it.

control.title: Posting work information to online services

part.name: SecurityControl0820
part.p: Personnel are advised to not post work information to unauthorised online services and to report cases where such information is posted.

control.title: Posting work information to online services

part.name: SecurityControl1146
part.p: Personnel are advised to maintain separate work and personal accounts for online services.

control.title: Posting personal information to online services

part.name: SecurityControl0821
part.p: Personnel are advised of security risks associated with posting personal information to online services and are encouraged to use any available privacy settings to restrict who can view such information.

control.title: Sending and receiving files via online services

part.name: SecurityControl0824
part.p: Personnel are advised not to send or receive files via unauthorised online services.

group.title: Access to systems and their resources

part.name: SecurityControl0432
part.p: Access requirements for a system and its resources are documented in its system security plan.

part.name: SecurityControl0434
part.p: Personnel undergo appropriate employment screening, and where necessary hold an appropriate security clearance, before being granted access to a system and its resources.

part.name: SecurityControl0435
part.p: Personnel receive any necessary briefings before being granted access to a system and its resources.

part.name: SecurityControl0414
part.p: Personnel granted access to a system and its resources are uniquely identifiable.

part.name: SecurityControl0415
part.p: The use of shared user accounts is strictly controlled, and personnel using such accounts are uniquely identifiable.

part.name: SecurityControl1583
part.p: Personnel who are contractors are identified as such.

part.name: SecurityControl0420
part.p: Where a system processes, stores or communicates AUSTEO, AGAO or REL data, personnel who are foreign nationals are identified as such, including by their specific nationality.

part.name: SecurityControl0405
part.p: Requests for unprivileged access to systems, applications and data repositories are validated when first requested.

part.name: SecurityControl1566
part.p: Use of unprivileged access is logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1714
part.p: Unprivileged access event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

control.title: Unprivileged access to systems by foreign nationals

part.name: SecurityControl0409
part.p: Foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, do not have access to systems that process, store or communicate AUSTEO or REL data unless effective security controls are in place to ensure such data is not accessible to them.

control.title: Unprivileged access to systems by foreign nationals

part.name: SecurityControl0411
part.p: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have access to systems that process, store or communicate AGAO data unless effective security controls are in place to ensure such data is not accessible to them.

part.name: SecurityControl1507
part.p: Requests for privileged access to systems and applications are validated when first requested.

part.name: SecurityControl1733
part.p: Requests for privileged access to data repositories are validated when first requested.

part.name: SecurityControl1508
part.p: Privileged access to systems and applications is limited to only what is required for users and services to undertake their duties.

part.name: SecurityControl1649
part.p: Just-in-time administration is used for administering systems and applications.

part.name: SecurityControl0445
part.p: Privileged users are assigned a dedicated privileged account to be used solely for tasks requiring privileged access.

part.name: SecurityControl1509
part.p: Use of privileged access is logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1650
part.p: Changes to privileged accounts and groups are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1651
part.p: Privileged access event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl1652
part.p: Privileged account and group change event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl1175
part.p: Privileged user accounts are prevented from accessing the internet, email and web services.

part.name: SecurityControl1653
part.p: Privileged service accounts are prevented from accessing the internet, email and web services.

control.title: Privileged access to systems by foreign nationals

part.name: SecurityControl0446
part.p: Foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems that process, store or communicate AUSTEO or REL data.

control.title: Privileged access to systems by foreign nationals

part.name: SecurityControl0447
part.p: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems that process, store or communicate AGAO data.

part.name: SecurityControl0430
part.p: Access to systems, applications and data repositories is removed or suspended on the same day personnel no longer have a legitimate requirement for access.

part.name: SecurityControl1591
part.p: Access to systems, applications and data repositories is removed or suspended as soon as practicable when personnel are detected undertaking malicious activities.

part.name: SecurityControl1404
part.p: Unprivileged access to systems and applications is automatically disabled after 45 days of inactivity.

part.name: SecurityControl1648
part.p: Privileged access to systems and applications is automatically disabled after 45 days of inactivity.

part.name: SecurityControl1716
part.p: Access to data repositories is automatically disabled after 45 days of inactivity.

part.name: SecurityControl1647
part.p: Privileged access to systems and applications is automatically disabled after 12 months unless revalidated.

part.name: SecurityControl1734
part.p: Privileged access to data repositories is automatically disabled after 12 months unless revalidated.

control.title: Recording authorisation for personnel to access systems

part.name: SecurityControl0407
part.p: A secure record is maintained for the life of each system covering: • all personnel authorised to access the system, and their user identification • who provided authorisation for access • when access was granted • the level of access that was granted • when access, and the level of access, was last reviewed • when the level of access was changed, and to what extent (if applicable) • when access was withdrawn (if applicable).

part.name: SecurityControl0441
part.p: When personnel are granted temporary access to a system, effective security controls are put in place to restrict their access to only data required for them to undertake their duties.

part.name: SecurityControl0443
part.p: Temporary access is not granted to systems that process, store or communicate caveated or sensitive compartmented information.

part.name: SecurityControl1610
part.p: A method of emergency access to systems is documented and tested at least once when initially implemented and each time fundamental information technology infrastructure changes occur.

part.name: SecurityControl1611
part.p: Break glass accounts are only used when normal authentication processes cannot be used.

part.name: SecurityControl1612
part.p: Break glass accounts are only used for specific authorised activities.

part.name: SecurityControl1613
part.p: Use of break glass accounts is logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1715
part.p: Break glass event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl1614
part.p: Break glass account credentials are changed by the account custodian after they are accessed by any other party.

part.name: SecurityControl1615
part.p: Break glass accounts are tested after credentials are changed.

part.name: SecurityControl0078
part.p: Systems processing, storing or communicating AUSTEO or AGAO data remain at all times under the control of an Australian national working for or on behalf of the Australian Government.

part.name: SecurityControl0854
part.p: AUSTEO and AGAO data can only be accessed from systems under the sole control of the Australian Government that are located within facilities authorised by the Australian Government.

part.name: SecurityControl0181
part.p: Cabling infrastructure is installed in accordance with relevant Australian Standards, as directed by the Australian Communications and Media Authority.

part.name: SecurityControl1111
part.p: Fibre-optic cables are used for cabling infrastructure instead of copper cables.

part.name: SecurityControl0211
part.p: A cable register is maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl0208
part.p: A cable register contains the following for each cable: • cable identifier • cable colour • sensitivity/classification • source • destination • location • seal numbers (if applicable).

part.name: SecurityControl1645
part.p: Floor plan diagrams are maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl1646
part.p: Floor plan diagrams contain the following: • cable paths (including ingress and egress points between floors) • cable reticulation system and conduit paths • floor concentration boxes • wall outlet boxes • network cabinets.

part.name: SecurityControl0206
part.p: Cable labelling processes, and supporting cable labelling procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1096
part.p: Cables are labelled at each end with sufficient source and destination details to enable the physical identification and inspection of the cable.

part.name: SecurityControl1639
part.p: Building management cables are labelled with their purpose in black writing on a yellow background, with a minimum size of 2.5 cm x 1 cm, and attached at five-metre intervals.

control.title: Labelling cables for foreign systems in Australian facilities

part.name: SecurityControl1640
part.p: Cables for foreign systems installed in Australian facilities are labelled at inspection points.

part.name: SecurityControl0926
part.p: OFFICIAL and PROTECTED cables are coloured neither salmon pink nor red.

part.name: SecurityControl1718
part.p: SECRET cables colours are coloured salmon pink.

part.name: SecurityControl1719
part.p: TOP SECRET cables colours are coloured red.

part.name: SecurityControl1216
part.p: SECRET and TOP SECRET cables with non-conformant cable colouring are both banded with the appropriate colour and labelled at inspection points.

part.name: SecurityControl1112
part.p: Cables are inspectable at a minimum of five-metre intervals.

part.name: SecurityControl1119
part.p: Cables in TOP SECRET areas are fully inspectable for their entire length.

control.title: Common cable reticulation systems and conduits

part.name: SecurityControl0187
part.p: SECRET and TOP SECRET systems belong exclusively to their own cable groups.

control.title: Common cable reticulation systems and conduits

part.name: SecurityControl0189
part.p: Cables only carry a single cable group, unless each cable group belongs to a different subunit.

control.title: Common cable reticulation systems and conduits

part.name: SecurityControl1114
part.p: Cable groups sharing a common cable reticulation system have a dividing partition or a visible gap between the cable groups.

part.name: SecurityControl1130
part.p: In shared facilities, cables are run in an enclosed cable reticulation system.

control.title: Covers for enclosed cable reticulation systems

part.name: SecurityControl1164
part.p: In shared facilities, conduits or the front covers of ducts, cable trays in floors and ceilings, and associated fittings are clear plastic.

control.title: Sealing cable reticulation systems and conduits

part.name: SecurityControl0195
part.p: In shared facilities, uniquely identifiable SCEC endorsed tamper-evident seals are used to seal all removable covers on TOP SECRET cable reticulation systems.

control.title: Sealing cable reticulation systems and conduits

part.name: SecurityControl0194
part.p: In shared facilities, a visible smear of conduit glue is used to seal all plastic conduit joints and TOP SECRET conduits connected by threaded lock nuts.

part.name: SecurityControl0201
part.p: Labels for TOP SECRET conduits are a minimum size of 2.5 cm x 1 cm, attached at five-metre intervals and marked as ‘TS RUN’.

part.name: SecurityControl1115
part.p: Cables from cable trays to wall outlet boxes are run in flexible or plastic conduit.

part.name: SecurityControl1133
part.p: In shared facilities, TOP SECRET cables are not run in party walls.

part.name: SecurityControl1122
part.p: Where wall penetrations exit a TOP SECRET area into a lower classified area, TOP SECRET cables are encased in conduit with all gaps between the TOP SECRET conduit and the wall filled with an appropriate sealing compound.

part.name: SecurityControl1104
part.p: Wall outlet boxes have connectors on opposite sides of the wall outlet box if the cable group contains cables belonging to different systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1105
part.p: Different cables groups do not share a wall outlet box.

part.name: SecurityControl1095
part.p: Wall outlet boxes denote the systems, cable identifiers and wall outlet box identifier.

part.name: SecurityControl1107
part.p: OFFICIAL and PROTECTED wall outlet boxes are coloured neither salmon pink nor red.

part.name: SecurityControl1720
part.p: SECRET wall outlet boxes are coloured salmon pink.

part.name: SecurityControl1721
part.p: TOP SECRET wall outlet boxes are coloured red.

part.name: SecurityControl1109
part.p: Wall outlet box covers are clear plastic.

part.name: SecurityControl0218
part.p: If TOP SECRET fibre-optic fly leads exceeding five metres in length are used to connect wall outlet boxes to ICT equipment, they are run in a protective and easily inspected pathway that is clearly labelled at the ICT equipment end with the wall outlet box’s identifier.

control.title: Connecting cable reticulation systems to cabinets

part.name: SecurityControl1102
part.p: Cable reticulation systems leading into cabinets are terminated as close as possible to the cabinet.

control.title: Connecting cable reticulation systems to cabinets

part.name: SecurityControl1101
part.p: In TOP SECRET areas, cable reticulation systems leading into cabinets in server rooms or communications rooms are terminated as close as possible to the cabinet.

control.title: Connecting cable reticulation systems to cabinets

part.name: SecurityControl1103
part.p: In TOP SECRET areas, cable reticulation systems leading into cabinets not in server rooms or communications rooms are terminated at the boundary of the cabinet.

part.name: SecurityControl1098
part.p: Cables are terminated in individual cabinets; or for small systems, one cabinet with a division plate to delineate cable groups.

part.name: SecurityControl1100
part.p: TOP SECRET cables are terminated in an individual TOP SECRET cabinet.

control.title: Terminating cable groups on patch panels

part.name: SecurityControl0213
part.p: Different cable groups do not terminate on the same patch panel.

control.title: Physical separation of cabinets and patch panels

part.name: SecurityControl1116
part.p: There is a visible gap between TOP SECRET cabinets and cabinets of lower classifications.

control.title: Physical separation of cabinets and patch panels

part.name: SecurityControl0216
part.p: TOP SECRET and non-TOP SECRET patch panels are physically separated by installing them in separate cabinets.

control.title: Physical separation of cabinets and patch panels

part.name: SecurityControl0217
part.p: Where spatial constraints demand patch panels of lower classifications than TOP SECRET be located in the same cabinet as a TOP SECRET patch panel: • a physical barrier in the cabinet is provided to separate patch panels • only personnel holding a Positive Vetting security clearance have access to the cabinet • approval from the TOP SECRET system’s authorising officer is obtained prior to installation.

part.name: SecurityControl0198
part.p: When penetrating a TOP SECRET audio secure room, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation is consulted and all directions provided are complied with.

part.name: SecurityControl1123
part.p: A power distribution board with a feed from an Uninterruptible Power Supply is used to power all TOP SECRET ICT equipment.

control.title: Emanation security threat assessments in Australia

part.name: SecurityControl0248
part.p: System owners deploying OFFICIAL or PROTECTED systems with Radio Frequency transmitters that will be co-located with SECRET or TOP SECRET systems contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the threat assessment.

control.title: Emanation security threat assessments in Australia

part.name: SecurityControl0247
part.p: System owners deploying SECRET or TOP SECRET systems with Radio Frequency transmitters inside or co-located with their facility contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the threat assessment.

control.title: Emanation security threat assessments in Australia

part.name: SecurityControl1137
part.p: System owners deploying SECRET or TOP SECRET systems in shared facilities contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the threat assessment.

control.title: Emanation security threat assessments outside Australia

part.name: SecurityControl0249
part.p: System owners deploying systems or military platforms overseas contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the threat assessment.

control.title: Early identification of emanation security controls

part.name: SecurityControl0246
part.p: An emanation security threat assessment is sought as early as possible in a project’s life cycle as emanation security controls can have significant cost implications.

part.name: SecurityControl0250
part.p: ICT equipment meets industry and government standards relating to electromagnetic interference/electromagnetic compatibility.

part.name: SecurityControl1078
part.p: A telephone system usage policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0229
part.p: Personnel are advised of the permitted sensitivity or classification of information that can be discussed over both internal and external telephone systems.

part.name: SecurityControl0230
part.p: Personnel are advised of security risks posed by non-secure telephone systems in areas where sensitive or classified conversations can occur.

part.name: SecurityControl0231
part.p: When using cryptographic equipment to permit different levels of conversation for different kinds of connections, telephone systems give a visual indication of what kind of connection has been made.

part.name: SecurityControl0232
part.p: Telephone systems used for sensitive or classified conversations encrypt all traffic that passes over external systems.

part.name: SecurityControl0233
part.p: Cordless telephone systems are not used for sensitive or classified conversations.

part.name: SecurityControl0235
part.p: Speakerphones are not used on telephone systems in TOP SECRET areas unless the telephone system is located in an audio secure room, the room is audio secure during conversations and only personnel involved in conversations are present in the room.

part.name: SecurityControl0236
part.p: Off-hook audio protection features are used on telephone systems in areas where background conversations may exceed the sensitivity or classification that the telephone system is authorised for communicating.

part.name: SecurityControl0931
part.p: In SECRET and TOP SECRET areas, push-to-talk handsets or push-to-talk headsets are used to meet any off-hook audio protection requirements.

group.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony

control.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony infrastructure hardening

part.name: SecurityControl1562
part.p: Video conferencing and IP telephony infrastructure is hardened.

part.name: SecurityControl0546
part.p: Where a requirement exists to implement a firewall in a gateway, and video conferencing or IP telephony traffic passes through the gateway, a video-aware and/or voice-aware firewall is used.

control.title: Protecting video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony traffic

part.name: SecurityControl0548
part.p: Video conferencing and IP telephony calls are established using a secure session initiation protocol.

control.title: Protecting video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony traffic

part.name: SecurityControl0547
part.p: Video conferencing and IP telephony calls are conducted using a secure real-time transport protocol.

control.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

part.name: SecurityControl0554
part.p: An encrypted and non-replayable two-way authentication scheme is used for call authentication and authorisation.

control.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

part.name: SecurityControl0553
part.p: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on a video conferencing network, including call setup and changing settings.

control.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

part.name: SecurityControl0555
part.p: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on an IP telephony network, including registering a new IP phone, changing phone users, changing settings and accessing voicemail.

control.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

part.name: SecurityControl0551
part.p: IP telephony is configured such that: • IP phones authenticate themselves to the call controller upon registration • auto-registration is disabled and only authorised devices are allowed to access the network • unauthorised devices are blocked by default • all unused and prohibited functionality is disabled.

control.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

part.name: SecurityControl1014
part.p: Individual logins are implemented for IP phones used for SECRET or TOP SECRET conversations.

part.name: SecurityControl0549
part.p: Video conferencing and IP telephony traffic is separated physically or logically from other data traffic.

part.name: SecurityControl0556
part.p: Workstations are not connected to video conferencing units or IP phones unless the workstation or the device uses Virtual Local Area Networks or similar mechanisms to maintain separation between video conferencing, IP telephony and other data traffic.

control.title: Internet Protocol phones in public areas

part.name: SecurityControl0558
part.p: IP phones used in public areas do not have the ability to access data networks, voicemail and directory services.

part.name: SecurityControl0559
part.p: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-SECRET workstations in SECRET areas.

part.name: SecurityControl1450
part.p: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-TOP SECRET workstations in TOP SECRET areas.

control.title: Developing a denial of service response plan

part.name: SecurityControl1019
part.p: A denial of service response plan is developed and implemented for video conferencing and IP telephony services that includes: • how to identify signs of a denial-of-service attack • how to identify the source of a denial-of-service attack • how capabilities can be maintained during a denial-of-service attack • what actions can be taken to respond to a denial-of-service attack.

control.title: Fax machine and multifunction device usage policy

part.name: SecurityControl0588
part.p: A fax machine and MFD usage policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1092
part.p: Separate fax machines or MFDs are used for sending sensitive or classified fax messages and all other fax messages.

part.name: SecurityControl0241
part.p: When sending fax messages, the fax message is encrypted to an appropriate level to be communicated over unsecured telecommunications infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl1075
part.p: The sender of a fax message makes arrangements for the receiver to collect the fax message as soon as possible after it is sent and for the receiver to notify the sender if the fax message does not arrive in an agreed amount of time.

part.name: SecurityControl0590
part.p: Security controls for MFDs connected to a network are of a similar strength to those for other devices on the network.

control.title: Connecting multifunction devices to both networks and digital telephone systems

part.name: SecurityControl0245
part.p: A direct connection from an MFD to a digital telephone system is not enabled unless the digital telephone system is authorised to operate at the same sensitivity or classification as the network to which the MFD is connected.

part.name: SecurityControl0589
part.p: MFDs connected to networks are not used to copy documents above the sensitivity or classification of the connected network.

control.title: Observing fax machine and multifunction device use

part.name: SecurityControl1036
part.p: Fax machines and MFDs are located in areas where their use can be observed.

part.name: SecurityControl1533
part.p: A mobile device management policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1195
part.p: A Mobile Device Management solution is used to ensure mobile device management policy is applied to all mobile devices.

part.name: SecurityControl0687
part.p: Mobile devices do not process, store or communicate SECRET or TOP SECRET data until approved for use by the ACSC.

part.name: SecurityControl1297
part.p: Legal advice is sought prior to allowing privately-owned mobile devices to access systems or data.

part.name: SecurityControl1400
part.p: Personnel accessing OFFICIAL and PROTECTED systems or data using a privately-owned mobile device use an ACSC approved platform, a security configuration in accordance with ACSC guidance and have enforced separation of work data from any personal data.

part.name: SecurityControl0694
part.p: Privately-owned mobile devices do not access SECRET and TOP SECRET systems or data.

part.name: SecurityControl1482
part.p: Personnel accessing systems or data using an organisation-owned mobile device use an ACSC approved platform with a security configuration in accordance with ACSC guidance.

part.name: SecurityControl0869
part.p: Mobile devices encrypt their internal storage and any removable media.

part.name: SecurityControl1085
part.p: Mobile devices encrypt all sensitive or classified data communicated over public network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl1196
part.p: Mobile devices are configured to remain undiscoverable to other Bluetooth devices except during Bluetooth pairing.

part.name: SecurityControl1200
part.p: Bluetooth pairing is performed using Secure Connections, preferably with Numeric Comparison if supported.

part.name: SecurityControl1198
part.p: Bluetooth pairing is performed in a manner such that connections are only made between intended Bluetooth devices.

part.name: SecurityControl1199
part.p: Bluetooth pairings are removed when there is no longer a requirement for their use.

part.name: SecurityControl0682
part.p: Bluetooth functionality is not enabled on SECRET and TOP SECRET mobile devices.

part.name: SecurityControl0863
part.p: Mobile devices prevent personnel from installing or uninstalling non-approved applications once provisioned.

part.name: SecurityControl0864
part.p: Mobile devices prevent personnel from disabling or modifying security functionality once provisioned.

part.name: SecurityControl1366
part.p: Security updates are applied to mobile devices as soon as they become available.

control.title: Connecting mobile devices to the internet

part.name: SecurityControl0874
part.p: Mobile devices access the internet via a VPN connection to an organisation’s internet gateway rather than via a direct connection to the internet.

control.title: Connecting mobile devices to the internet

part.name: SecurityControl0705
part.p: When accessing an organisation’s network via a VPN connection, split tunnelling is disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1082
part.p: A mobile device usage policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1083
part.p: Personnel are advised of the sensitivity or classification permitted for voice and data communications when using mobile devices.

control.title: Paging, message services and messaging apps

part.name: SecurityControl0240
part.p: Paging, Multimedia Message Service, Short Message Service and messaging apps are not used to communicate sensitive or classified data.

control.title: Using mobile devices in public spaces

part.name: SecurityControl0866
part.p: Sensitive or classified data is not viewed or communicated in public locations unless care is taken to reduce the chance of the screen of a mobile device being observed.

control.title: Using mobile devices in public spaces

part.name: SecurityControl1145
part.p: Privacy filters are applied to the screens of SECRET and TOP SECRET mobile devices.

control.title: Using mobile devices in public spaces

part.name: SecurityControl1644
part.p: Sensitive or classified phone calls are not conducted in public locations unless care is taken to reduce the chance of conversations being overheard.

part.name: SecurityControl0871
part.p: Mobile devices are kept under continual direct supervision when being actively used.

part.name: SecurityControl0870
part.p: Mobile devices are carried or stored in a secured state when not being actively used.

part.name: SecurityControl1084
part.p: If unable to carry or store mobile devices in a secured state, they are physically transferred in a security briefcase or an approved multi-use satchel, pouch or transit bag.

control.title: Mobile device emergency sanitisation processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl0701
part.p: Mobile device emergency sanitisation processes, and supporting mobile device emergency sanitisation procedures, are developed and implemented.

control.title: Mobile device emergency sanitisation processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl0702
part.p: If a cryptographic zeroise or sanitise function is provided for cryptographic keys on a SECRET or TOP SECRET mobile device, the function is used as part of mobile device emergency sanitisation processes and procedures.

control.title: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1298
part.p: Personnel are advised of privacy and security risks when travelling overseas with mobile devices.

control.title: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1554
part.p: If travelling overseas with mobile devices to high or extreme risk countries, personnel are: • issued with newly provisioned accounts, mobile devices and removable media from a pool of dedicated travel devices which are used solely for work-related activities • advised on how to apply and inspect tamper seals to key areas of mobile devices • advised to avoid taking any personal mobile devices, especially if rooted or jailbroken.

control.title: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1555
part.p: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions: • record all details of the mobile devices being taken, such as product types, serial numbers and International Mobile Equipment Identity numbers • update all operating systems and applications • remove all non-essential accounts, applications and data • apply security configuration settings, such as lock screens • configure remote locate and wipe functionality • enable encryption, including for any removable media • backup all important data and configuration settings.

control.title: While travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1299
part.p: Personnel take the following precautions when travelling overseas with mobile devices: • never leaving mobile devices or removable media unattended for any period of time, including by placing them in checked-in luggage or leaving them in hotel safes • never storing credentials with mobile devices that they grant access to, such as in laptop bags • never lending mobile devices or removable media to untrusted people, even if briefly • never allowing untrusted people to connect their mobile devices or removable media, including for charging • never using designated charging stations, wall outlet charging ports or chargers supplied by untrusted people • avoiding connecting mobile devices to open or untrusted Wi-Fi networks • using a VPN connection to encrypt all mobile device communications • using encrypted messaging apps for communications instead of using foreign telecommunication networks • disabling any communications capabilities of mobile devices when not in use, such as cellular data, wireless, Bluetooth and Near Field Communication • avoiding reuse of removable media once used with other parties’ systems or mobile devices • ensuring any removable media used for data transfers are thoroughly checked for malicious code beforehand • never using any gifted mobile devices, especially removable media, when travelling or upon returning from travelling.

control.title: While travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1088
part.p: Personnel report the potential compromise of mobile devices, removable media or credentials to their organisation as soon as possible, especially if they: • provide credentials to foreign government officials • decrypt mobile devices for foreign government officials • have mobile devices taken out of sight by foreign government officials • have mobile devices or removable media stolen that are later returned • lose mobile devices or removable media that are later found • observe unusual behaviour of mobile devices.

control.title: After travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1300
part.p: Upon returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions: • sanitise and reset mobile devices, including all removable media • decommission any physical credentials that left their possession during their travel • report if significant doubt exists as to the integrity of any mobile devices or removable media.

control.title: After travelling overseas with mobile devices

part.name: SecurityControl1556
part.p: If returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices to high or extreme risk countries, personnel take the following additional actions: • reset user credentials used with mobile devices, including those used for remote access to their organisation’s systems • monitor accounts for any indicators of compromise, such as failed login attempts.

part.name: SecurityControl0280
part.p: If procuring an evaluated product, a product that has completed a PP-based evaluation is selected in preference to one that has completed an EAL-based evaluation.

part.name: SecurityControl0285
part.p: Evaluated products are delivered in a manner consistent with any delivery procedures defined in associated evaluation documentation.

part.name: SecurityControl0286
part.p: When procuring high assurance ICT equipment, the ACSC is contacted for any equipment-specific delivery procedures.

control.title: Installation and configuration of evaluated products

part.name: SecurityControl0289
part.p: Evaluated products are installed, configured, administered and operated in accordance with vendor guidance and evaluation documentation.

control.title: Installation and configuration of evaluated products

part.name: SecurityControl0290
part.p: High assurance ICT equipment is installed, configured, administered and operated in accordance with guidance produced by the ACSC.

control.title: Use of high assurance ICT equipment in unevaluated configurations

part.name: SecurityControl0292
part.p: High assurance ICT equipment is always operated in an evaluated configuration.

part.name: SecurityControl1551
part.p: An ICT equipment management policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0336
part.p: An ICT equipment register is maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl0294
part.p: ICT equipment, with the exception of high assurance ICT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0296
part.p: The Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC)’s approval is sought before applying labels to external surfaces of high assurance ICT equipment.

part.name: SecurityControl0293
part.p: ICT equipment is classified based on the highest sensitivity or classification of data that it is approved for processing, storing or communicating.

part.name: SecurityControl1599
part.p: ICT equipment is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

control.title: Maintenance and repairs of high assurance ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1079
part.p: The ACSC’s approval is sought before undertaking any maintenance or repairs to high assurance ICT equipment.

part.name: SecurityControl0305
part.p: Maintenance and repairs of ICT equipment is carried out on site by an appropriately cleared technician.

part.name: SecurityControl0307
part.p: If an uncleared technician is used to undertake maintenance or repairs of ICT equipment, the ICT equipment and associated media is sanitised before maintenance or repair work is undertaken.

part.name: SecurityControl0306
part.p: If an uncleared technician is used to undertake maintenance or repairs of ICT equipment, the technician is escorted by someone who: • is appropriately cleared and briefed • takes due care to ensure that data is not disclosed • takes all responsible measures to ensure the integrity of the ICT equipment • has the authority to direct the technician • is sufficiently familiar with the ICT equipment to understand the work being performed.

part.name: SecurityControl0310
part.p: ICT equipment maintained or repaired off site is done so in accordance with the handling requirements for the sensitivity or classification of the ICT equipment.

control.title: Inspection of ICT equipment following maintenance and repairs

part.name: SecurityControl1598
part.p: Following maintenance or repair activities for ICT equipment, the ICT equipment is inspected to confirm it retains its approved software configuration and that no unauthorised modifications have taken place.

control.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl0313
part.p: ICT equipment sanitisation processes, and supporting ICT equipment sanitisation procedures, are developed and implemented.

control.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl1550
part.p: ICT equipment disposal processes, and supporting ICT equipment disposal procedures, are developed and implemented.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1217
part.p: Labels and markings indicating the owner, sensitivity, classification or any other marking that can associate ICT equipment with its prior use are removed prior to its disposal.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl0311
part.p: When disposing of ICT equipment containing media, the ICT equipment is sanitised by sanitising the media within the ICT equipment, removing the media from the ICT equipment or destroying the ICT equipment in its entirety.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl0315
part.p: When disposing of high assurance ICT equipment, it is destroyed prior to its disposal.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl0321
part.p: When disposing of ICT equipment that has been designed or modified to meet emanation security standards, the ACSC is contacted for requirements relating to its disposal.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl0316
part.p: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to release ICT equipment, or its waste, into the public domain.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of highly sensitive ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1218
part.p: ICT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed, stored or communicated AUSTEO or AGAO data, is sanitised in situ.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of highly sensitive ICT equipment

part.name: SecurityControl0312
part.p: ICT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed, stored or communicated AUSTEO or AGAO data that cannot be sanitised in situ, is returned to Australia for destruction.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

part.name: SecurityControl0317
part.p: At least three pages of random text with no blank areas are printed on each colour printer cartridge or MFD print drum.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

part.name: SecurityControl1219
part.p: MFD print drums and image transfer rollers are inspected and destroyed if there is remnant toner which cannot be removed or a print is visible on the image transfer roller.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

part.name: SecurityControl1220
part.p: Printer and MFD platens are inspected and destroyed if any text or images are retained on the platen.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

part.name: SecurityControl1221
part.p: Printers and MFDs are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

part.name: SecurityControl0318
part.p: When unable to sanitise printer cartridges or MFD print drums, they are destroyed as per electrostatic memory devices.

control.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

part.name: SecurityControl1534
part.p: Printer ribbons in printers and MFDs are removed and destroyed.

part.name: SecurityControl1076
part.p: Televisions and computer monitors with minor burn-in or image persistence are sanitised by displaying a solid white image on the screen for an extended period of time.

part.name: SecurityControl1222
part.p: Televisions and computer monitors that cannot be sanitised are destroyed.

part.name: SecurityControl1223
part.p: Memory in network devices is sanitised using the following processes, in order of preference: • following device-specific guidance provided in evaluation documentation • following vendor sanitisation guidance • loading a dummy configuration file, performing a factory reset and then reinstalling firmware.

part.name: SecurityControl1225
part.p: The paper tray of the fax machine is removed, and a fax message with a minimum length of four pages is transmitted, before the paper tray is re-installed to allow a fax summary page to be printed.

part.name: SecurityControl1226
part.p: Fax machines are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

part.name: SecurityControl1549
part.p: A media management policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1359
part.p: A removable media usage policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1713
part.p: A removable media register is maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl0332
part.p: Media, with the exception of internally mounted fixed media within ICT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0323
part.p: Media is classified to the highest sensitivity or classification of data it stores, unless the media has been classified to a higher sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0337
part.p: Media is only used with systems that are authorised to process, store or communicate its sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0325
part.p: Any media connected to a system with a higher sensitivity or classification than the media is reclassified to the higher sensitivity or classification, unless the media is read-only or the system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

part.name: SecurityControl0330
part.p: Before reclassifying media to a lower sensitivity or classification, it is either sanitised or the data it stores is reclassified in consultation with data owners, and a formal administrative decision is made to reclassify the media.

part.name: SecurityControl0831
part.p: Media is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl1059
part.p: All data stored on media is encrypted.

part.name: SecurityControl1600
part.p: Media is sanitised before it is used for the first time.

part.name: SecurityControl1642
part.p: Media is sanitised before it is reused in a different security domain.

part.name: SecurityControl0347
part.p: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, write-once media is used unless the destination system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

part.name: SecurityControl0947
part.p: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, rewritable media is sanitised after each data transfer.

part.name: SecurityControl0348
part.p: Media sanitisation processes, and supporting media sanitisation procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0351
part.p: Volatile media is sanitised by removing its power for at least 10 minutes.

part.name: SecurityControl0352
part.p: SECRET and TOP SECRET volatile media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

control.title: Treatment of volatile media following sanitisation

part.name: SecurityControl0835
part.p: Following sanitisation, TOP SECRET volatile media retains its classification if it stored static data for an extended period of time, or had data repeatedly stored on or written to the same memory location for an extended period of time.

part.name: SecurityControl0354
part.p: Non-volatile magnetic media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once (or three times if pre-2001 or under 15 GB) in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

part.name: SecurityControl1065
part.p: The host-protected area and device configuration overlay table are reset prior to the sanitisation of non-volatile magnetic hard drives.

part.name: SecurityControl1067
part.p: The ATA secure erase command is used, in addition to block overwriting software, to ensure the growth defects table of non-volatile magnetic hard drives is overwritten.

control.title: Treatment of non-volatile magnetic media following sanitisation

part.name: SecurityControl0356
part.p: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile magnetic media retains its classification.

control.title: Non-volatile erasable programmable read-only memory media sanitisation

part.name: SecurityControl0357
part.p: Non-volatile EPROM media is sanitised by applying three times the manufacturer’s specified ultraviolet erasure time and then overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

control.title: Non-volatile electrically erasable programmable read-only memory media sanitisation

part.name: SecurityControl0836
part.p: Non-volatile EEPROM media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

control.title: Treatment of non-volatile erasable and electrically erasable programmable read-only memory media following sanitisation

part.name: SecurityControl0358
part.p: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile EPROM and EEPROM media retains its classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0359
part.p: Non-volatile flash memory media is sanitised by overwriting it at least twice in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

control.title: Treatment of non-volatile flash memory media following sanitisation

part.name: SecurityControl0360
part.p: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile flash memory media retains its classification.

control.title: Media that cannot be successfully sanitised

part.name: SecurityControl1735
part.p: Faulty or damaged media that cannot be successfully sanitised is destroyed prior to its disposal.

part.name: SecurityControl0363
part.p: Media destruction processes, and supporting media destruction procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0350
part.p: The following media types are destroyed prior to their disposal: • microfiche and microfilm • optical discs • programmable read-only memory • read-only memory • other types of media that cannot be sanitised.

part.name: SecurityControl1361
part.p: SCEC or ASIO approved equipment is used when destroying media.

part.name: SecurityControl1160
part.p: If using degaussers to destroy media, degaussers evaluated by the United States’ National Security Agency are used.

part.name: SecurityControl1517
part.p: Equipment that is capable of reducing microform to a fine powder, with resultant particles not showing more than five consecutive characters per particle upon microscopic inspection, is used to destroy microfiche and microfilm.

part.name: SecurityControl1722
part.p: Electrostatic memory devices are destroyed using either furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator or grinder/sander destruction methods.

part.name: SecurityControl1723
part.p: Magnetic floppy disks are destroyed using either furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, cutting or degausser destruction methods.

part.name: SecurityControl1724
part.p: Magnetic hard disks are destroyed using either furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or degausser destruction methods.

part.name: SecurityControl1725
part.p: Magnetic tapes are destroyed using either furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, cutting or degausser destruction methods.

part.name: SecurityControl1726
part.p: Optical disks are destroyed using either furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or cutting destruction methods.

part.name: SecurityControl1727
part.p: Semiconductor memory is destroyed using either furnace/incinerator, hammer mill or disintegrator destruction methods.

part.name: SecurityControl0368
part.p: Media destroyed using either a hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or cutting destruction method result in media waste particles no larger than 9 mm.

part.name: SecurityControl1728
part.p: The resulting media waste particles from the destruction of SECRET media is stored and handled as OFFICIAL if less than or equal to 3 mm, PROTECTED if greater than 3 mm and less than or equal to 6 mm, or SECRET if greater than 6 mm and less than or equal to 9 mm.

part.name: SecurityControl1729
part.p: The resulting media waste particles from the destruction of TOP SECRET media is stored and handled as OFFICIAL if less than or equal to 3 mm, or SECRET if greater than 3 mm and less than or equal to 9 mm.

part.name: SecurityControl0361
part.p: Magnetic media is destroyed using a degausser with a suitable magnetic field strength and magnetic orientation.

part.name: SecurityControl0362
part.p: Any product-specific directions provided by degausser manufacturers are followed.

part.name: SecurityControl1641
part.p: Following destruction of magnetic media using a degausser, it is physically damaged (such as by deforming the internal platters of hard drives) prior to its disposal.

part.name: SecurityControl0370
part.p: The destruction of media is performed under the supervision of at least one person cleared to its sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0371
part.p: Personnel supervising the destruction of media supervise its handling to the point of destruction and ensure that the destruction is completed successfully.

part.name: SecurityControl0372
part.p: The destruction of media storing accountable material is performed under the supervision of at least two personnel cleared to its sensitivity or classification.

part.name: SecurityControl0373
part.p: Personnel supervising the destruction of media storing accountable material supervise its handling to the point of destruction, ensure that the destruction is completed successfully and sign a destruction certificate afterwards.

part.name: SecurityControl0840
part.p: When outsourcing the destruction of media to an external destruction service, a National Association for Information Destruction AAA certified destruction service with endorsements, as specified in ASIO’s PSC-167, is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0839
part.p: The destruction of media storing accountable material is not outsourced.

part.name: SecurityControl0374
part.p: Media disposal processes, and supporting media disposal procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0378
part.p: Labels and markings indicating the owner, sensitivity, classification or any other marking that can associate media with its prior use are removed prior to its disposal.

part.name: SecurityControl0375
part.p: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to release media, or its waste, into the public domain.

part.name: SecurityControl1406
part.p: SOEs are used for workstations and servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1608
part.p: SOEs provided by third parties are scanned for malicious content and configurations before being used.

part.name: SecurityControl1588
part.p: SOEs are reviewed and updated at least annually.

part.name: SecurityControl1407
part.p: The latest release, or the previous release, of operating systems are used for workstations, servers and network devices.

part.name: SecurityControl1408
part.p: When developing a Microsoft Windows SOE, the 64-bit version of the operating system is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1409
part.p: ACSC and vendor guidance is implemented to assist in hardening the configuration of operating systems.

part.name: SecurityControl0383
part.p: Default operating system accounts are disabled, renamed or have their passphrase changed.

part.name: SecurityControl0380
part.p: Unneeded operating system accounts, software, components, services and functionality are disabled or removed.

part.name: SecurityControl0341
part.p: Automatic execution features for removable media are disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1654
part.p: Internet Explorer 11 is disabled or removed.

part.name: SecurityControl1655
part.p: .NET Framework 3.5 (includes .NET 2.0 and 3.0) is disabled or removed.

part.name: SecurityControl1584
part.p: Unprivileged users are prevented from bypassing, disabling or modifying security functionality of operating systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1491
part.p: Unprivileged users are prevented from running script execution engines in Microsoft Windows, including: • Windows Script Host (cscript.exe and wscript.exe) • PowerShell (powershell.exe, powershell_ise.exe and pwsh.exe) • Command Prompt (cmd.exe) • Windows Management Instrumentation (wmic.exe) • Microsoft Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) Application Host (mshta.exe).

part.name: SecurityControl1410
part.p: Local administrator accounts are disabled; alternatively, passphrases that are random and unique for each device’s local administrator account are used.

part.name: SecurityControl1469
part.p: Unique domain accounts with local administrative privileges, but without domain administrative privileges, are used for workstation and server management.

part.name: SecurityControl1592
part.p: Users do not have the ability to install unapproved software.

part.name: SecurityControl0382
part.p: Users do not have the ability to uninstall or disable approved software.

part.name: SecurityControl0843
part.p: Application control is implemented on workstations.

part.name: SecurityControl1490
part.p: Application control is implemented on internet-facing servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1656
part.p: Application control is implemented on non-internet-facing servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1657
part.p: Application control restricts the execution of executables, software libraries, scripts, installers, compiled HTML, HTML applications and control panel applets to an organisation-approved set.

part.name: SecurityControl1658
part.p: Application control restricts the execution of drivers to an organisation-approved set.

part.name: SecurityControl0955
part.p: Application control is implemented using cryptographic hash rules, publisher certificate rules or path rules.

part.name: SecurityControl1582
part.p: Application control rulesets are validated on an annual or more frequent basis.

part.name: SecurityControl1471
part.p: When implementing application control using publisher certificate rules, both publisher names and product names are used.

part.name: SecurityControl1392
part.p: When implementing application control using path rules, file system permissions are configured to prevent unauthorised modification of folder and file permissions, folder contents (including adding new files) and individual files that are approved to execute.

part.name: SecurityControl1544
part.p: Microsoft’s ‘recommended block rules’ are implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1659
part.p: Microsoft’s ‘recommended driver block rules’ are implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0846
part.p: All users (with the exception of privileged users when performing specific administrative activities) cannot disable, bypass or be exempted from application control.

part.name: SecurityControl1660
part.p: Allowed and blocked executions on workstations are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1661
part.p: Allowed and blocked executions on internet-facing servers are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1662
part.p: Allowed and blocked executions on non-internet facing servers are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl0957
part.p: Application control event logs including the name of the file, the date/time stamp and the username of the user associated with the event.

part.name: SecurityControl1663
part.p: Application control event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl1492
part.p: Microsoft’s exploit protection functionality is implemented on workstations and servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1621
part.p: Windows PowerShell 2.0 is disabled or removed.

part.name: SecurityControl1622
part.p: PowerShell is configured to use Constrained Language Mode.

part.name: SecurityControl1623
part.p: PowerShell is configured to use module logging, script block logging and transcription functionality.

part.name: SecurityControl1624
part.p: PowerShell script block logs are protected by Protected Event Logging functionality.

part.name: SecurityControl1664
part.p: Blocked PowerShell script executions are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1665
part.p: PowerShell event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl1341
part.p: A HIPS is implemented on workstations.

part.name: SecurityControl1034
part.p: A HIPS is implemented on high value servers such as authentication servers, Domain Name System servers, web servers, file servers and email servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1416
part.p: A software firewall is implemented on workstations and servers to limit both inbound and outbound network connections.

part.name: SecurityControl1417
part.p: Antivirus software is implemented on workstations and servers and configured with: • signature-based detection enabled and set to a high level • heuristic-based detection enabled and set to a high level • ransomware protection measures enabled • detection signatures checked for currency and updated on at least a daily basis • automatic and regular scanning configured for all fixed disks and removable media.

part.name: SecurityControl1390
