part.p: Antivirus software has reputation rating functionality enabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1418
part.p: Unauthorised removable media and devices are prevented from being connected to workstations and servers via the use of device access control software or by disabling external communication interfaces in operating systems.

part.name: SecurityControl0345
part.p: External communication interfaces that allow DMA are disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl0343
part.p: Removable media is prevented from being written to via the use of device access control software if there is no business requirement for its use.

part.name: SecurityControl0938
part.p: Applications are chosen from vendors that have made a commitment to secure development and maintenance practices.

part.name: SecurityControl1467
part.p: The latest releases of office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF software, and security products are used when present within SOEs.

part.name: SecurityControl1483
part.p: The latest releases of web server software, server applications that store important data, and other internet-accessible server applications are used when present within SOEs.

part.name: SecurityControl1486
part.p: Web browsers do not process Java from the internet.

part.name: SecurityControl1485
part.p: Web browsers do not process web advertisements from the internet.

part.name: SecurityControl1666
part.p: Internet Explorer 11 does not process content from the internet.

part.name: SecurityControl1667
part.p: Microsoft Office is blocked from creating child processes.

part.name: SecurityControl1668
part.p: Microsoft Office is blocked from creating executable content.

part.name: SecurityControl1669
part.p: Microsoft Office is blocked from injecting code into other processes.

part.name: SecurityControl1542
part.p: Microsoft Office is configured to prevent activation of Object Linking and Embedding packages.

part.name: SecurityControl1670
part.p: PDF software is blocked from creating child processes.

part.name: SecurityControl1412
part.p: ACSC or vendor hardening guidance for web browsers, Microsoft Office and PDF software is implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1470
part.p: Any unrequired functionality in web browsers, Microsoft Office and PDF software is disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1235
part.p: The use of web browser, Microsoft Office and PDF software add-ons is restricted to organisation approved add-ons.

part.name: SecurityControl1601
part.p: If supported, Microsoft’s Attack Surface Reduction rules are implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1585
part.p: Web browsers, Microsoft Office and PDF software security settings cannot be changed by users.

part.name: SecurityControl1671
part.p: Microsoft Office macros are disabled for users that do not have a demonstrated business requirement.

part.name: SecurityControl1488
part.p: Microsoft Office macros in files originating from the internet are blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl1672
part.p: Microsoft Office macro antivirus scanning is enabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1673
part.p: Microsoft Office macros are blocked from making Win32 API calls.

part.name: SecurityControl1674
part.p: Only Microsoft Office macros running from within a sandboxed environment, a Trusted Location or that are digitally signed by a trusted publisher are allowed to execute.

part.name: SecurityControl1487
part.p: Only privileged users responsible for validating that Microsoft Office macros are free of malicious code can write to and modify content within Trusted Locations.

part.name: SecurityControl1675
part.p: Microsoft Office macros digitally signed by an untrusted publisher cannot be enabled via the Message Bar or Backstage View.

part.name: SecurityControl1676
part.p: Microsoft Office’s list of trusted publishers is validated on an annual or more frequent basis.

part.name: SecurityControl1489
part.p: Microsoft Office macro security settings cannot be changed by users.

part.name: SecurityControl1677
part.p: Allowed and blocked Microsoft Office macro executions are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1678
part.p: Microsoft Office macro event logs are logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl1546
part.p: Users are authenticated before they are granted access to a system and its resources.

part.name: SecurityControl0974
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate unprivileged users of systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1173
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate privileged users of systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1504
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is used by an organisation’s users if they authenticate to their organisation’s internet-facing services.

part.name: SecurityControl1679
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is used by an organisation’s users if they authenticate to third-party internet-facing services that process, store or communicate their organisation's sensitive data.

part.name: SecurityControl1680
part.p: Multi-factor authentication (where available) is used by an organisation’s users if they authenticate to third-party internet-facing services that process, store or communicate their organisation's non-sensitive data.

part.name: SecurityControl1681
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is enabled by default for non-organisational users (but users can choose to opt out) if they authenticate to an organisation’s internet-facing services.

part.name: SecurityControl1505
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users accessing important data repositories.

part.name: SecurityControl1401
part.p: Multi-factor authentication uses either: something users have and something users know, or something users have that is unlocked by something users know or are.

part.name: SecurityControl1682
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is verifier impersonation resistant.

part.name: SecurityControl1559
part.p: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication are a minimum of 6 characters, unless more stringent requirements apply.

part.name: SecurityControl1560
part.p: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication on SECRET systems are a minimum of 8 characters.

part.name: SecurityControl1561
part.p: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication on TOP SECRET systems are a minimum of 10 characters.

part.name: SecurityControl1357
part.p: When multi-factor authentication is implemented, none of the authentication factors on their own can be used for single-factor authentication to another system.

part.name: SecurityControl1683
part.p: Successful and unsuccessful multi-factor authentications are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl1684
part.p: Multi-factor authentication event logs are centrally stored and protected from unauthorised modification and deletion, monitored for signs of compromise, and actioned when cyber security events are detected.

part.name: SecurityControl0417
part.p: When systems cannot support multi-factor authentication, single-factor authentication using passphrases is implemented instead.

part.name: SecurityControl0421
part.p: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication are at least 4 random words with a total minimum length of 14 characters, unless more stringent requirements apply.

part.name: SecurityControl1557
part.p: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication on SECRET systems are at least 5 random words with a total minimum length of 17 characters.

part.name: SecurityControl0422
part.p: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication on TOP SECRET systems are at least 6 random words with a total minimum length of 20 characters.

part.name: SecurityControl1558
part.p: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication: • are not constructed from song lyrics, movies, literature or any other publicly available material • do not form a real sentence in a natural language • are not a list of categorised words.

part.name: SecurityControl1596
part.p: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication can not be used to authenticate to multiple different systems.

control.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

part.name: SecurityControl1227
part.p: Passwords/passphrases set or reset on users’ behalf are randomly generated.

control.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

part.name: SecurityControl1593
part.p: Users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when collecting a password/passphrase for their account.

control.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

part.name: SecurityControl1594
part.p: Passwords/passphrases are provided to users via a secure communications channel or, if not possible, split into parts with part being provided to the user and part provided to the user’s supervisor.

control.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

part.name: SecurityControl1595
part.p: Users that do not set their own initial password/passphrase are required to change it on first use.

control.title: Setting and resetting credentials for service accounts

part.name: SecurityControl1619
part.p: Service accounts are created as group Managed Service Accounts.

part.name: SecurityControl1403
part.p: Accounts are locked out after a maximum of five failed logon attempts.

part.name: SecurityControl0431
part.p: Repeated account lockouts are investigated before reauthorising access.

part.name: SecurityControl0976
part.p: Users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when requesting an account unlock.

part.name: SecurityControl1603
part.p: Authentication methods susceptible to replay attacks are disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1055
part.p: LAN Manager and NT LAN Manager authentication methods are disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1620
part.p: Privileged accounts are members of the Protected Users security group.

part.name: SecurityControl1685
part.p: Credentials for local administrator accounts and service accounts are unique, unpredictable and managed.

part.name: SecurityControl0418
part.p: Credentials are stored separately from systems to which they grant access.

part.name: SecurityControl1597
part.p: Credentials are obscured as they are entered into systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1402
part.p: Stored passwords/passphrases are protected by ensuring they are hashed, salted and stretched.

part.name: SecurityControl1686
part.p: Windows Defender Credential Guard and Windows Defender Remote Credential Guard are enabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1590
part.p: Passwords/passphrases are changed if: • they are directly compromised • they are suspected of being compromised • they appear in online data breach databases • they are discovered stored in the clear on a network • they are discovered being transferred in the clear across a network • membership of a shared account changes • they have not been changed in the past 12 months.

part.name: SecurityControl0853
part.p: Outside of business hours, and after an appropriate period of inactivity, user sessions are terminated and workstations are rebooted.

part.name: SecurityControl0428
part.p: Systems are configured with a session or screen lock that: • activates after a maximum of 15 minutes of user inactivity, or if manually activated by the user • conceals all session content on the screen • ensures that the screen does not enter a power saving state before the session or screen lock is activated • requires the user to reauthenticate to unlock the system • denies users the ability to disable the session or screen locking mechanism.

part.name: SecurityControl0408
part.p: Systems have a logon banner that requires users to acknowledge and accept their security responsibilities before access is granted.

part.name: SecurityControl0979
part.p: Legal advice is sought on the exact wording of logon banners.

part.name: SecurityControl1460
part.p: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the isolation mechanism is from a vendor that uses secure coding practices and, when security vulnerabilities have been identified, develops and distributes patches in a timely manner.

part.name: SecurityControl1604
part.p: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the configuration of the isolation mechanism is hardened by removing unneeded functionality and restricting access to the administrative interface used to manage the isolation mechanism.

part.name: SecurityControl1605
part.p: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the underlying operating system running on the server is hardened.

part.name: SecurityControl1606
part.p: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, patches are applied to the isolation mechanism and underlying operating system in a timely manner.

part.name: SecurityControl1607
part.p: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, integrity and log monitoring are performed for the isolation mechanism and underlying operating system in a timely manner.

part.name: SecurityControl1461
part.p: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware for SECRET or TOP SECRET workloads, the physical server and all computing environments running on the physical server are of the same classification and within the same security domain.

part.name: SecurityControl0042
part.p: System administration processes, and supporting system administration procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1380
part.p: Privileged users use separate privileged and unprivileged operating environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1687
part.p: Privileged operating environments are not virtualised within unprivileged operating environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1688
part.p: Unprivileged accounts cannot logon to privileged operating environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1689
part.p: Privileged accounts (excluding local administrator accounts) cannot logon to unprivileged operating environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1381
part.p: Dedicated administrator workstations used for privileged tasks are prevented from communicating to assets not related to administrative activities.

part.name: SecurityControl1383
part.p: All administrative infrastructure including, but not limited to, administrator workstations and jump servers are hardened.

control.title: Dedicated administration zones and communication restrictions

part.name: SecurityControl1385
part.p: Administrator workstations are placed into a separate network zone to user workstations.

part.name: SecurityControl1386
part.p: Management traffic is only allowed to originate from network zones that are used to administer systems and applications.

part.name: SecurityControl1387
part.p: Administrative activities are conducted through jump servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1388
part.p: Jump servers are prevented from communicating to assets and sending and receiving traffic not related to administrative activities.

part.name: SecurityControl1143
part.p: Patch management processes, and supporting patch management procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1493
part.p: Software registers are maintained and regularly audited for workstations, servers, mobile devices, network devices and all other ICT equipment.

part.name: SecurityControl1643
part.p: Software registers contain versions and patch histories of applications, drivers, operating systems and firmware.

part.name: SecurityControl1690
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in internet-facing services are applied within two weeks of release, or within 48 hours if an exploit exists.

part.name: SecurityControl1691
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF software, and security products are applied within two weeks of release.

part.name: SecurityControl1692
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF software, and security products are applied within 48 hours if an exploit exists.

part.name: SecurityControl1693
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in other applications are applied within one month.

part.name: SecurityControl1694
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in operating systems of internet-facing services are applied within two weeks of release, or within 48 hours if an exploit exists.

part.name: SecurityControl1695
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, servers and network devices are applied within two weeks of release.

part.name: SecurityControl1696
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, servers and network devices are applied within 48 hours if an exploit exists.

part.name: SecurityControl1697
part.p: Patches, updates or vendor mitigations for security vulnerabilities in drivers and firmware are applied within two weeks of release, or within 48 hours if an exploit exists.

part.name: SecurityControl0300
part.p: High assurance ICT equipment is only patched or updated when approved by the ACSC using methods and timeframes prescribed by the ACSC.

part.name: SecurityControl0298
part.p: A centralised and managed approach is used to patch or update applications and drivers.

part.name: SecurityControl0303
part.p: An approach for patching or updating applications and drivers that ensures the integrity and authenticity of patches or updates, as well as the processes used to apply them, is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1497
part.p: An automated mechanism is used to confirm and record that deployed application and driver patches or updates have been installed, applied successfully and remain in place.

part.name: SecurityControl1498
part.p: A centralised and managed approach is used to patch or update operating systems and firmware.

part.name: SecurityControl1499
part.p: An approach for patching or updating operating systems and firmware that ensures the integrity and authenticity of patches or updates, as well as the processes used to apply them, is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1500
part.p: An automated mechanism is used to confirm and record that deployed operating system and firmware patches or updates have been installed, applied successfully and remain in place.

part.name: SecurityControl1698
part.p: A vulnerability scanner is used at least daily to identify missing patches or updates for security vulnerabilities in internet-facing services.

part.name: SecurityControl1699
part.p: A vulnerability scanner is used at least weekly to identify missing patches or updates for security vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF software, and security products.

part.name: SecurityControl1700
part.p: A vulnerability scanner is used at least fortnightly to identify missing patches or updates for security vulnerabilities in other applications.

part.name: SecurityControl1701
part.p: A vulnerability scanner is used at least daily to identify missing patches for security vulnerabilities in operating systems of internet-facing services.

part.name: SecurityControl1702
part.p: A vulnerability scanner is used at least weekly to identify missing patches for security vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, servers and network devices.

part.name: SecurityControl1703
part.p: A vulnerability scanner is used at least weekly to identify missing patches for security vulnerabilities in drivers and firmware.

part.name: SecurityControl1704
part.p: Internet-facing services, office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF software, Adobe Flash Player, and security products that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

part.name: SecurityControl0304
part.p: Applications that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

part.name: SecurityControl1501
part.p: Operating systems that are no longer supported by vendors are replaced.

part.name: SecurityControl1211
part.p: Change management processes, and supporting change management procedures, are developed and implemented covering: • identification and documentation of requests for change • approval required for changes to be made • assessment of potential security impacts • notification of any planned disruptions or outages • implementation and testing of approved changes • the maintenance of system and security documentation.

part.name: SecurityControl1510
part.p: A digital preservation policy is developed and implemented.

control.title: Data backup and restoration processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl1547
part.p: Data backup processes, and supporting data backup procedures, are developed and implemented.

control.title: Data backup and restoration processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl1548
part.p: Data restoration processes, and supporting data restoration procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1511
part.p: Backups of important data, software and configuration settings are performed and retained in a coordinated and resilient manner in accordance with business continuity requirements.

part.name: SecurityControl1705
part.p: Unprivileged accounts, and privileged accounts (excluding backup administrators) cannot access other account’s backups.

part.name: SecurityControl1706
part.p: Unprivileged accounts, and privileged accounts (excluding backup administrators) can’t access their own account’s backups.

part.name: SecurityControl1707
part.p: Unprivileged accounts, and privileged accounts (excluding backup administrators), are prevented from modifying or deleting backups.

part.name: SecurityControl1708
part.p: Backup administrators (excluding backup break glass accounts), are prevented from modifying or deleting backups.

part.name: SecurityControl1515
part.p: Restoration of systems, software and important data from backups is tested in a coordinated manner as part of disaster recovery exercises.

part.name: SecurityControl0580
part.p: An event logging policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1405
part.p: A centralised logging facility is implemented and systems are configured to save event logs to the centralised logging facility as soon as possible after each event occurs.

part.name: SecurityControl0988
part.p: An accurate time source is established and used consistently across systems and network devices to assist with the correlation of events.

part.name: SecurityControl0584
part.p: For any system requiring authentication, logon, failed logon and logoff events are logged.

part.name: SecurityControl0582
part.p: The following events are logged for operating systems: • access to important data and processes • application crashes and any error messages • attempts to use special privileges • changes to accounts • changes to security policy • changes to system configurations • Domain Name System and Hypertext Transfer Protocol requests • failed attempts to access data and system resources • service failures and restarts • system startup and shutdown • transfer of data to and from external media • user or group management • use of special privileges.

part.name: SecurityControl1536
part.p: The following events are logged for web applications: • attempted access that is denied • crashes and any error messages • search queries initiated by users.

part.name: SecurityControl1537
part.p: The following events are logged for databases: • access to particularly important data • addition of new users, especially privileged users • any query containing comments • any query containing multiple embedded queries • any query or database alerts or failures • attempts to elevate privileges • attempted access that is successful or unsuccessful • changes to the database structure • changes to user roles or database permissions • database administrator actions • database logons and logoffs • modifications to data • use of executable commands.

part.name: SecurityControl0585
part.p: For each event logged, the date and time of the event, the relevant user or process, the event description, and the ICT equipment involved are recorded.

part.name: SecurityControl0586
part.p: Event logs are protected from unauthorised access, modification and deletion.

part.name: SecurityControl0859
part.p: Event logs are retained for a minimum of 7 years in accordance with the NAA’s Administrative Functions Disposal Authority Express Version 2 publication.

part.name: SecurityControl0991
part.p: Domain Name System and proxy logs are retained for at least 18 months.

control.title: Event log auditing processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl0109
part.p: Event log auditing processes, and supporting event log auditing procedures, are developed and implemented covering the scope and schedule of audits, what constitutes a violation of security policy, and actions to be taken when violations are detected, including reporting requirements.

control.title: Event log auditing processes and procedures

part.name: SecurityControl1228
part.p: Events are correlated across event logs to prioritise audits and focus investigations.

part.name: SecurityControl0400
part.p: Development, testing and production environments are segregated.

part.name: SecurityControl1419
part.p: Development and modification of software only takes place in development environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1420
part.p: Data in production environments is not used in testing or development environments unless the testing or development environments are secured to the same level as the production environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1422
part.p: Unauthorised access to the authoritative source for software is prevented.

part.name: SecurityControl1238
part.p: Threat modelling and other secure design techniques are used to ensure that threats to software and mitigations to those threats are identified and accounted for.

part.name: SecurityControl1730
part.p: A software bill of materials is produced and made available to consumers of software.

part.name: SecurityControl0401
part.p: Platform-specific secure programming practices are used when developing software, including using the lowest privilege needed to achieve a task, checking return values of all system calls, validating all inputs and encrypting all communications.

part.name: SecurityControl0402
part.p: Software is tested for security vulnerabilities by software developers, as well as an independent party, before it is used in a production environment.

part.name: SecurityControl1616
part.p: A vulnerability disclosure program is implemented to assist with the secure development and maintenance of products and services.

part.name: SecurityControl1717
part.p: A ‘security.txt’ file is hosted for all internet-facing organisational domains to assist in the responsible disclosure of security vulnerabilities in organisations’ products and services.

part.name: SecurityControl1239
part.p: Robust web application frameworks are used to aid in the development of secure web applications.

part.name: SecurityControl1552
part.p: All web application content is offered exclusively using HTTPS.

part.name: SecurityControl1240
part.p: Validation and/or sanitisation is performed on all input handled by a web application.

part.name: SecurityControl1241
part.p: Output encoding is performed on all output produced by a web application.

part.name: SecurityControl1424
part.p: Web applications implement Content-Security-Policy, HSTS and X-Frame-Options response headers.

part.name: SecurityControl0971
part.p: The OWASP Application Security Verification Standard is followed when developing web applications.

part.name: SecurityControl1425
part.p: Hard disks of database servers are encrypted using full disk encryption.

control.title: Functional separation between database servers and web servers

part.name: SecurityControl1269
part.p: Database servers and web servers are functionally separated, physically or virtually.

control.title: Communications between database servers and web servers

part.name: SecurityControl1277
part.p: Data communicated between database servers and web applications is encrypted.

part.name: SecurityControl1270
part.p: Database servers that require network connectivity are placed on a different network segment to an organisation’s workstations.

part.name: SecurityControl1271
part.p: Network access controls are implemented to restrict database server communications to strictly defined network resources such as web servers, application servers and storage area networks.

part.name: SecurityControl1272
part.p: If only local access to a database is required, networking functionality of database management system (DBMS) software is disabled or directed to listen solely to the localhost interface.

control.title: Separation of production, test and development database servers

part.name: SecurityControl1273
part.p: Test and development environments do not use the same database servers as production environments.

part.name: SecurityControl1245
part.p: All temporary installation files and logs are removed after DBMS software has been installed.

part.name: SecurityControl1246
part.p: DBMS software is configured according to vendor guidance.

part.name: SecurityControl1247
part.p: DBMS software features, stored procedures, accounts and databases that are not required are disabled or removed.

part.name: SecurityControl1249
part.p: DBMS software is configured to run as a separate account with the minimum privileges needed to perform its functions.

part.name: SecurityControl1250
part.p: The account under which DBMS software runs has limited access to non-essential areas of the database server’s file system.

part.name: SecurityControl1251
part.p: The ability of DBMS software to read local files from a server is disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1260
part.p: Default database administrator accounts are disabled, renamed or have their passphrases changed.

part.name: SecurityControl1262
part.p: Database administrators have unique and identifiable accounts.

part.name: SecurityControl1261
part.p: Database administrator accounts are not shared across different databases.

part.name: SecurityControl1263
part.p: Database administrator accounts are used exclusively for administrative activities, with standard database accounts used for general purpose interactions with databases.

part.name: SecurityControl1264
part.p: Database administrator access is restricted to defined roles rather than accounts with default administrative permissions, or all permissions.

part.name: SecurityControl1243
part.p: A database register is maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl1256
part.p: File-based access controls are applied to database files.

part.name: SecurityControl1252
part.p: Passphrases stored in databases are hashed with a uniquely salted Australian Signals Directorate Approved Cryptographic Algorithm.

part.name: SecurityControl0393
part.p: Databases and their contents are classified based on the sensitivity or classification of data that they contain.

part.name: SecurityControl1255
part.p: Database users’ ability to access, insert, modify and remove content in databases is restricted based on their work duties.

part.name: SecurityControl1268
part.p: The need-to-know principle is enforced for database contents through the application of minimum privileges, database views and database roles.

part.name: SecurityControl1258
part.p: Where concerns exist that the sum, or aggregation, of separate pieces of data from within databases could lead to a database user determining more sensitive or classified data, database views in combination with database user access roles are implemented.

control.title: Separation of production, test and development databases

part.name: SecurityControl1274
part.p: Data in production databases is not used in testing or development databases unless the testing or development environments are secured to the same level as the production environment.

part.name: SecurityControl1275
part.p: All queries to databases from web applications are filtered for legitimate content and correct syntax.

part.name: SecurityControl1276
part.p: Parameterised queries or stored procedures are used for database interaction instead of dynamically generated queries.

part.name: SecurityControl1278
part.p: Web applications are designed to provide as little error information as possible to users about database schemas.

part.name: SecurityControl0264
part.p: An email usage policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0267
part.p: Access to non-approved webmail services is blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl0270
part.p: Protective markings are applied to emails and reflect the highest sensitivity or classification of the subject, body and attachments.

part.name: SecurityControl0271
part.p: Protective marking tools do not automatically insert protective markings into emails.

part.name: SecurityControl0272
part.p: Protective marking tools do not allow users to select protective markings that a system has not been authorised to process, store or communicate.

part.name: SecurityControl1089
part.p: Protective marking tools do not allow users replying to or forwarding an email to select a protective marking that is lower than previously used for the email.

control.title: Handling emails with inappropriate, invalid or missing protective markings

part.name: SecurityControl0565
part.p: Email servers are configured to block, log and report emails with inappropriate protective markings.

control.title: Handling emails with inappropriate, invalid or missing protective markings

part.name: SecurityControl1023
part.p: The intended recipients of any blocked inbound emails, and the sender of any blocked outbound emails, are notified.

part.name: SecurityControl0269
part.p: Emails containing Australian Eyes Only, Australian Government Access Only or Releasable To data are only sent to named recipients and not to groups or distribution lists unless the nationality of all members of the distribution lists can be confirmed.

part.name: SecurityControl0569
part.p: Email is routed through a centralised email gateway.

part.name: SecurityControl0571
part.p: When users send email from outside their network, an authenticated and encrypted channel is configured to allow email to be routed via a centralised email gateway.

part.name: SecurityControl0570
part.p: Where backup or alternative email gateways are in place, they are maintained at the same standard as the primary email gateway.

part.name: SecurityControl0567
part.p: Email servers only relay emails destined for or originating from their domains.

part.name: SecurityControl0572
part.p: Opportunistic TLS encryption is enabled on email servers that make incoming or outgoing email connections over public network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl1589
part.p: MTA-STS is enabled to prevent the transfer of unencrypted emails between complying servers.

part.name: SecurityControl0574
part.p: SPF is used to specify authorised email services (or lack thereof) for all domains.

part.name: SecurityControl1183
part.p: A hard fail SPF record is used when specifying email servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1151
part.p: SPF is used to verify the authenticity of incoming emails.

part.name: SecurityControl1152
part.p: Incoming emails that fail SPF checks are blocked or marked in a manner that is visible to the recipients.

part.name: SecurityControl0861
part.p: DKIM signing is enabled on emails originating from an organisation’s domains.

part.name: SecurityControl1026
part.p: DKIM signatures on received emails are verified.

part.name: SecurityControl1027
part.p: Email distribution list software used by external senders is configured such that it does not break the validity of the sender’s DKIM signature.

control.title: Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance

part.name: SecurityControl1540
part.p: DMARC records are configured for all domains such that emails are rejected if they fail SPF or DKIM checks.

part.name: SecurityControl1234
part.p: Email content filtering controls are implemented for email bodies and attachments.

part.name: SecurityControl1502
part.p: Emails arriving via an external connection where the source address uses an internal domain name are blocked at the email gateway.

part.name: SecurityControl1024
part.p: Notification of undeliverable, bounced or blocked emails are only sent to senders that can be verified via SPF or other trusted means.

part.name: SecurityControl0516
part.p: Network documentation includes a high-level network diagram showing all connections into the network; a logical network diagram showing all network devices, critical servers and services; and the configuration of all network devices.

part.name: SecurityControl0518
part.p: Network documentation is updated as network configuration changes are made and includes a ‘current as at [date]’ or equivalent statement.

part.name: SecurityControl1178
part.p: Network documentation provided to a third party, or published in public tender documentation, only contains details necessary for other parties to undertake contractual services.

part.name: SecurityControl1181
part.p: Networks are divided into multiple functional network zones according to the sensitivity or criticality of data or services.

part.name: SecurityControl1577
part.p: Organisation networks are segregated from service provider networks.

part.name: SecurityControl1532
part.p: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between organisations’ networks and public network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl0529
part.p: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between networks belonging to different security domains.

part.name: SecurityControl1364
part.p: Network devices managing VLANs terminate VLANs belonging to different security domains on separate physical network interfaces.

part.name: SecurityControl0535
part.p: Network devices managing VLANs belonging to different security domains do not share VLAN trunks.

part.name: SecurityControl0530
part.p: Network devices managing VLANs are administered from the most trusted security domain.

part.name: SecurityControl0521
part.p: IPv6 functionality is disabled in dual-stack network devices and ICT equipment unless it is being used.

part.name: SecurityControl1186
part.p: IPv6 capable network security devices are used on IPv6 and dual-stack networks.

part.name: SecurityControl1428
part.p: Unless explicitly required, IPv6 tunnelling is disabled on all network devices and ICT equipment.

part.name: SecurityControl1429
part.p: IPv6 tunnelling is blocked by network security devices at externally-connected network boundaries.

part.name: SecurityControl1430
part.p: Dynamically assigned IPv6 addresses are configured with Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol version 6 in a stateful manner with lease data stored in a centralised logging facility.

part.name: SecurityControl0520
part.p: Network access controls are implemented on networks to prevent the connection of unauthorised network devices.

part.name: SecurityControl1182
part.p: Network access controls are implemented to limit traffic within and between network segments to only those that are required for business purposes.

part.name: SecurityControl1301
part.p: A network device register is maintained and regularly audited.

part.name: SecurityControl1304
part.p: Default accounts for network devices are disabled, renamed or have their passphrase changed.

control.title: Disabling unused physical ports on network devices

part.name: SecurityControl0534
part.p: Unused physical ports on network devices are disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl0385
part.p: Servers maintain effective functional separation with other servers allowing them to operate independently.

part.name: SecurityControl1479
part.p: Servers minimise communications with other servers at both the network and file system level.

part.name: SecurityControl1006
part.p: Security measures are implemented to prevent unauthorised access to network management traffic.

control.title: Use of Simple Network Management Protocol

part.name: SecurityControl1311
part.p: SNMP version 1 and 2 are not used on networks.

control.title: Use of Simple Network Management Protocol

part.name: SecurityControl1312
part.p: All default SNMP community strings on network devices are changed and have write access disabled.

control.title: Using Network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems

part.name: SecurityControl1028
part.p: NIDS or NIPS are deployed in all gateways between an organisation’s networks and other networks they do not manage.

control.title: Using Network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems

part.name: SecurityControl1030
part.p: NIDS or NIPS in gateways are located immediately inside the outermost firewall and configured to generate a log entry, and an alert, for any data flows that contravene any rule in firewall rule sets.

control.title: Using Network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems

part.name: SecurityControl1185
part.p: When deploying NIDS or NIPS in non-internet gateways, they are configured to monitor unusual patterns of behaviour or traffic flows rather than internet-based communication protocol signatures.

part.name: SecurityControl1627
part.p: Inbound network connections from anonymity networks to internet-facing services are blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl1628
part.p: Outbound network connections to anonymity networks are blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl1314
part.p: All wireless devices are Wi-Fi Alliance certified.

part.name: SecurityControl0536
part.p: Wireless networks provided for the general public to access are segregated from all other networks.

control.title: Administrative interfaces for wireless access points

part.name: SecurityControl1315
part.p: The administrative interface on wireless access points is disabled for wireless network connections.

part.name: SecurityControl1316
part.p: The default SSID of wireless access points is changed.

part.name: SecurityControl1317
part.p: The SSID of a non-public wireless network is not readily associated with an organisation, the location of their premises or the functionality of the wireless network.

part.name: SecurityControl1318
part.p: SSID broadcasting is enabled on wireless networks.

part.name: SecurityControl1709
part.p: Default accounts and passphrases of wireless devices are changed.

part.name: SecurityControl1710
part.p: Configuration settings for wireless devices are hardened.

part.name: SecurityControl1319
part.p: Static addressing is not used for assigning IP addresses on wireless networks.

part.name: SecurityControl1320
part.p: MAC address filtering is not used to restrict which devices can connect to wireless networks.

control.title: Confidentiality and integrity of wireless network traffic

part.name: SecurityControl1332
part.p: WPA3-Enterprise 192-bit mode is used to protect the confidentiality and integrity of all wireless network traffic.

part.name: SecurityControl1321
part.p: 802.1X authentication with EAP-TLS, using X.509 certificates, is used for mutual authentication; with all other EAP methods disabled on supplications and authentication servers.

part.name: SecurityControl1711
part.p: User identity confidentiality is used if available with EAP-TLS implementations.

part.name: SecurityControl1322
part.p: Evaluated supplicants, authenticators, wireless access points and authentication servers are used in wireless networks.

control.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

part.name: SecurityControl1324
part.p: Certificates are generated using an evaluated certificate authority solution or hardware security module.

control.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

part.name: SecurityControl1323
part.p: Certificates are required for both devices and users accessing wireless networks.

control.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

part.name: SecurityControl1327
part.p: Certificates are protected by encryption, user authentication, and both logical and physical access controls.

part.name: SecurityControl1330
part.p: The PMK caching period is not set to greater than 1440 minutes (24 hours).

part.name: SecurityControl1712
part.p: The use of FT (802.11r) is disabled unless authenticator-to-authenticator communications are secured by an ASD Approved Cryptographic Protocol.

control.title: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service authentication

part.name: SecurityControl1454
part.p: Communications between authenticators and a RADIUS server are encapsulated with an additional layer of encryption using RADIUS over Internet Protocol Security or RADIUS over Transport Layer Security.

part.name: SecurityControl1334
part.p: Wireless networks implement sufficient frequency separation from other wireless networks.

control.title: Protecting management frames on wireless networks

part.name: SecurityControl1335
part.p: Wireless access points enable the use of the 802.11w amendment to protect management frames.

part.name: SecurityControl1338
part.p: Instead of deploying a small number of wireless access points that broadcast on high power, a greater number of wireless access points that use less broadcast power are deployed to achieve the desired footprint.

part.name: SecurityControl1013
part.p: The effective range of wireless communications outside an organisation’s area of control is limited by implementing RF shielding on facilities in which SECRET or TOP SECRET wireless networks are used.

part.name: SecurityControl1437
part.p: A cloud service provider is used for hosting online services.

part.name: SecurityControl1578
part.p: Organisations are notified by cloud service providers of any change to configured regions or availability zones for online services.

control.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

part.name: SecurityControl1579
part.p: Cloud service providers’ ability to dynamically scale resources due to a genuine spike in demand or a denial-of-service attack is tested as part of capacity planning processes for online services.

control.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

part.name: SecurityControl1580
part.p: Where a high availability requirement exists for online services, the services are architected to automatically transition between availability zones.

control.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

part.name: SecurityControl1441
part.p: Where a requirement for high availability exists for online services, a denial of service mitigation service is used.

control.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

part.name: SecurityControl1581
part.p: Organisations perform continuous real-time monitoring of the availability of online services.

part.name: SecurityControl1438
part.p: Where a high availability requirement exists for website hosting, CDNs that cache websites are used.

part.name: SecurityControl1439
part.p: If using a CDN, disclosing the IP address of the web server under the organisation’s control (referred to as the origin server) is avoided and access to the origin server is restricted to the CDN and an authorised management network.

part.name: SecurityControl1431
part.p: Denial-of-service attack prevention and mitigation strategies are discussed with cloud service providers, specifically: • their capacity to withstand denial-of-service attacks • any costs likely to be incurred as a result of denial-of-service attacks • thresholds for notification of denial-of-service attacks • thresholds for turning off online services during denial-of-service attacks • pre-approved actions that can be undertaken during denial-of-service attacks • denial-of-service attack prevention arrangements with upstream service providers to block malicious traffic as far upstream as possible.

part.name: SecurityControl1458
part.p: The functionality and quality of online services, how to maintain such functionality, and what functionality can be lived without during a denial-of-service attack, are determined and documented.

part.name: SecurityControl1432
part.p: Domain names for online services are protected via registrar locking and confirming domain registration details are correct.

control.title: Monitoring with real-time alerting for online services

part.name: SecurityControl1435
part.p: Availability monitoring with real-time alerting is implemented for online services to detect denial-of-service attacks and measure their impact.

part.name: SecurityControl1436
part.p: Critical online services are segregated from other online services that are more likely to be targeted.

part.name: SecurityControl1518
part.p: A static version of a website is pre-prepared that requires minimal processing and bandwidth in order to facilitate at least a basic level of service when under a denial-of-service attack.

part.name: SecurityControl0457
part.p: Encryption software that has completed a Common Criteria evaluation against a Protection Profile is used when encrypting media that contains OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED data.

part.name: SecurityControl0460
part.p: HACE is used when encrypting media that contains SECRET or TOP SECRET data.

part.name: SecurityControl0459
part.p: Full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition, is implemented when encrypting data at rest.

control.title: Encrypting highly sensitive data at rest

part.name: SecurityControl1080
part.p: In addition to any encryption already in place, an ASD Approved Cryptographic Algorithm (AACA) is used to encrypt AUSTEO and AGAO data when at rest on a system.

part.name: SecurityControl0455
part.p: Where practical, cryptographic equipment and encryption software provides a means of data recovery to allow for circumstances where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure.

control.title: Handling encrypted ICT equipment and media

part.name: SecurityControl0462
part.p: When a user authenticates to encryption functionality for ICT equipment or media storing encrypted data, it is treated in accordance with its original sensitivity or classification until such a time that the user deauthenticates from the encryption functionality.

part.name: SecurityControl0465
part.p: Cryptographic equipment or encryption software that has completed a Common Criteria evaluation against a Protection Profile is used to protect OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED data when communicated over insufficiently secure networks, outside of appropriately secure areas or via public network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl0467
part.p: HACE is used to protect SECRET and TOP SECRET data when communicated over insufficiently secure networks, outside of appropriately secure areas or via public network infrastructure.

control.title: Encrypting highly sensitive data in transit

part.name: SecurityControl0469
part.p: In addition to any encryption already in place, an ASD Approved Cryptographic Protocol (AACP) is used to protect AUSTEO and AGAO data when communicated across network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl0471
part.p: Only AACAs or high assurance cryptographic algorithms are used by cryptographic equipment and software.

part.name: SecurityControl0994
part.p: ECDH and ECDSA are used in preference to DH and DSA.

part.name: SecurityControl0472
part.p: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1629
part.p: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus and associated parameters are selected according to NIST SP 800-56A Rev. 3.

part.name: SecurityControl0473
part.p: When using DSA for digital signatures, a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1630
part.p: When using DSA for digital signatures, a modulus and associated parameters are generated according to FIPS 186-4.

part.name: SecurityControl1446
part.p: When using elliptic curve cryptography, a curve from FIPS 186-4 is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0474
part.p: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a base point order and key size of at least 224 bits is used.

control.title: Using the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm

part.name: SecurityControl0475
part.p: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, a base point order and key size of at least 224 bits is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0476
part.p: When using RSA for digital signatures, and passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0477
part.p: When using RSA for digital signatures, and for passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a key pair for passing encrypted session keys that is different from the key pair used for digital signatures is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0479
part.p: Symmetric cryptographic algorithms are not used in Electronic Codebook Mode.

control.title: Cryptographic algorithms for use with High Assurance Cryptographic Equipment

part.name: SecurityControl1232
part.p: AACAs used by HACE are implemented in an ASD approved configuration, with preference given to CNSA Suite algorithms and key sizes.

part.name: SecurityControl0481
part.p: Only AACPs or high assurance cryptographic protocols are used by cryptographic equipment and software.

part.name: SecurityControl1139
part.p: Only the latest version of TLS is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1369
part.p: AES in Galois Counter Mode is used for symmetric encryption.

part.name: SecurityControl1370
part.p: Only server-initiated secure renegotiation is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1372
part.p: DH or ECDH is used for key establishment.

part.name: SecurityControl1448
part.p: When using DH or ECDH for key establishment, the ephemeral variant is used.

part.name: SecurityControl1373
part.p: Anonymous DH is not used.

part.name: SecurityControl1374
part.p: SHA-2-based certificates are used.

part.name: SecurityControl1375
part.p: Cipher suites are configured to use SHA-2 as part of the Message Authentication Code and Pseudo-Random Function.

part.name: SecurityControl1553
part.p: TLS compression is disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl1453
part.p: PFS is used for TLS connections.

part.name: SecurityControl1506
part.p: The use of SSH version 1 is disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl0484
part.p: The SSH daemon is configured to: • only listen on the required interfaces (ListenAddress xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx) • have a suitable login banner (Banner x) • have a login authentication timeout of no more than 60 seconds (LoginGraceTime 60) • disable host-based authentication (HostbasedAuthentication no) • disable rhosts-based authentication (IgnoreRhosts yes) • disable the ability to login directly as root (PermitRootLogin no) • disable empty passwords (PermitEmptyPasswords no) • disable connection forwarding (AllowTCPForwarding no) • disable gateway ports (GatewayPorts no) • disable X11 forwarding (X11Forwarding no).

part.name: SecurityControl0485
part.p: Public key-based authentication is used for SSH connections.

part.name: SecurityControl1449
part.p: SSH private keys are protected with a passphrase or a key encryption key.

part.name: SecurityControl0487
part.p: When using logins without a passphrase for automated purposes, the following are disabled: • access from IP addresses that do not require access • port forwarding • agent credential forwarding • X11 display remoting • console access.

part.name: SecurityControl0488
part.p: If using remote access without the use of a passphrase, the ‘forced command’ option is used to specify what command is executed and parameter checked is enabled.

part.name: SecurityControl0489
part.p: When SSH-agent or other similar key caching programs are used, it is only on workstations and servers with screen locks, key caches are set to expire within four hours of inactivity, and agent credential forwarding is enabled only when SSH traversal is required.

part.name: SecurityControl0490
part.p: Versions of S/MIME earlier than 3.0 are not used.

part.name: SecurityControl0494
part.p: Tunnel mode is used for IPsec connections; however, if using transport mode, an IP tunnel is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0496
part.p: The ESP protocol is used for IPsec connections.

part.name: SecurityControl1233
part.p: IKE is used for key exchange when establishing an IPsec connection.

control.title: Internet Security Association Key Management Protocol modes

part.name: SecurityControl0497
part.p: If using ISAKMP in IKE version 1, aggressive mode is disabled.

part.name: SecurityControl0498
part.p: A security association lifetime of less than four hours, or 14400 seconds, is used.

part.name: SecurityControl0998
part.p: HMAC-SHA256, HMAC-SHA384 or HMAC-SHA512 is used as a HMAC algorithm.

part.name: SecurityControl0999
part.p: The largest modulus size possible for all relevant components in the network is used when conducting a key exchange.

part.name: SecurityControl1000
part.p: PFS is used for IPsec connections.

part.name: SecurityControl1001
part.p: The use of XAuth is disabled for IPsec connections using IKE version 1.

part.name: SecurityControl0501
part.p: Keyed cryptographic equipment is transported based on the sensitivity or classification of the keying material in it.

part.name: SecurityControl0142
part.p: The compromise or suspected compromise of cryptographic equipment or associated keying material is reported to an organisation’s Chief Information Security Officer, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after it occurs.

part.name: SecurityControl1091
part.p: Keying material is changed when compromised or suspected of being compromised.

part.name: SecurityControl0499
part.p: All communications security and equipment-specific doctrine produced by the ACSC for the management and use of HACE is complied with.

part.name: SecurityControl0506
part.p: Areas in which HACE is used are separated from other areas and designated as a cryptographic controlled area.

part.name: SecurityControl0628
part.p: All systems are protected from systems in other security domains by one or more gateways.

part.name: SecurityControl1192
part.p: All connections between security domains implement mechanisms to inspect and filter data flows for the transport and higher layers as defined in the OSI model.

part.name: SecurityControl0631
part.p: Gateways: • are the only communications paths into and out of internal networks • allow only explicitly authorised connections • are managed via a secure path isolated from all connected networks (physically at the gateway or on a dedicated administration network) • log all physical and logical access to their components • are configured to save logs to a secure logging facility • have all security controls tested to verify their effectiveness after any changes to their configuration.

part.name: SecurityControl1427
part.p: Gateways implement ingress traffic filtering to detect and prevent Internet Protocol (IP) source address spoofing.

part.name: SecurityControl0634
part.p: All gateways connecting networks in different security domains are operated such that they: • log network traffic permitted through the gateway • log network traffic attempting to leave the gateway • are configured to save event logs to a secure logging facility • provide real-time alerts for any cyber security incidents, attempted intrusions and unusual usage patterns.

part.name: SecurityControl0637
part.p: Demilitarised zones are used to broker access to services accessed by external entities, and mechanisms are applied to mediate internal and external access to less-trusted services hosted in these demilitarised zones.

part.name: SecurityControl1037
part.p: Gateways are subject to rigorous testing, performed at irregular intervals no more than six months apart, to determine the strength of security controls.

part.name: SecurityControl0611
part.p: Access to gateway administration functions is limited to the minimum roles and privileges to support the gateway securely.

part.name: SecurityControl0612
part.p: System administrators are formally trained to manage gateways.

part.name: SecurityControl1520
part.p: All system administrators of gateways are cleared to access the highest level of data communicated or processed by the gateway.

part.name: SecurityControl0613
part.p: All system administrators of gateways that process Australian Eyes Only or Australian Government Access Only data are Australian nationals.

part.name: SecurityControl0616
part.p: Roles for the administration of gateways are separated.

part.name: SecurityControl0629
part.p: For gateways between networks in different security domains, a formal arrangement exists whereby any shared components are managed by the system managers of the highest security domain or by a mutually agreed third party.

part.name: SecurityControl0607
part.p: Once connectivity is established, system owners become stakeholders for all connected security domains.

part.name: SecurityControl0619
part.p: Users and services accessing networks through gateways are authenticated.

part.name: SecurityControl0620
part.p: Only users and services authenticated and authorised to a gateway can use the gateway.

part.name: SecurityControl1039
part.p: Multi-factor authentication is used for access to gateways.

part.name: SecurityControl0622
part.p: ICT equipment accessing networks through gateways is authenticated.

control.title: When to implement a Cross Domain Solution

part.name: SecurityControl0626
part.p: When connecting a SECRET or TOP SECRET network to any other network from a different security domain, a CDS is implemented.

control.title: Consultation when implementing or modifying a Cross Domain Solution

part.name: SecurityControl0597
part.p: When designing and deploying a CDS, the ACSC is notified and consulted; and directions provided by the ACSC are complied with.

control.title: Consultation when implementing or modifying a Cross Domain Solution

part.name: SecurityControl0627
part.p: When introducing additional connectivity to a CDS, such as adding a new gateway to a common network, the ACSC is consulted on the impact to the security of the CDS; and directions provided by the ACSC are complied with.

part.name: SecurityControl0635
part.p: A CDS implements isolated upward and downward network paths.

part.name: SecurityControl1521
part.p: A CDS implements protocol breaks at each layer of the OSI model.

part.name: SecurityControl1522
part.p: A CDS implements content filtering and separate independent security-enforcing components for upward and downward data flows.

part.name: SecurityControl0670
part.p: All security-relevant events generated by a CDS are logged and regularly analysed.

part.name: SecurityControl1523
part.p: A representative sample of security events generated by a CDS, relating to the enforcement of data transfer policies, is taken at least every 3 months and assessed against the security policies that the CDS is responsible for enforcing between security domains.

part.name: SecurityControl0610
part.p: Users are trained on the secure use of a CDS before access to the CDS is granted.

part.name: SecurityControl1528
part.p: An evaluated firewall is used between organisations’ networks and public network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl0639
part.p: An evaluated firewall is used between networks belonging to different security domains.

part.name: SecurityControl1194
part.p: The requirement to use a firewall as part of gateway infrastructure is met by both parties independently; shared ICT equipment does not satisfy the requirements of both parties.

part.name: SecurityControl0643
part.p: An evaluated diode is used for controlling the data flow of a unidirectional gateway between an organisation’s network and public network infrastructure.

part.name: SecurityControl0645
part.p: An evaluated diode used for controlling the data flow of a unidirectional gateway between a SECRET or TOP SECRET network and public network infrastructure completes a high assurance evaluation.

part.name: SecurityControl1157
part.p: An evaluated diode is used for controlling the data flow of a unidirectional gateway between networks.

part.name: SecurityControl1158
part.p: An evaluated diode used for controlling the data flow of a unidirectional gateway between a SECRET or TOP SECRET network and any other network completes a high assurance evaluation.

part.name: SecurityControl0648
part.p: A diode (or server connected to the diode) deployed to control data flow in unidirectional gateways monitors the volume of the data being transferred.

part.name: SecurityControl0258
part.p: A web usage policy is developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0260
part.p: All web access, including that by internal servers, is conducted through a web proxy.

part.name: SecurityControl0261
part.p: A web proxy authenticates users and provides logging that includes the following details about websites accessed: • address (uniform resource locator) • time/date • user • amount of data uploaded and downloaded • internal and external IP addresses.

part.name: SecurityControl0963
part.p: A web content filter is used to filter potentially harmful web-based content.

part.name: SecurityControl0961
part.p: Client-side active content, such as Java, is restricted to a list of allowed websites.

part.name: SecurityControl1237
part.p: Web content filtering controls are applied to outbound web traffic where appropriate.

part.name: SecurityControl0263
part.p: For TLS traffic communicated through internet gateways, either of the following approaches are implemented: • a solution that decrypts and inspects all TLS traffic as per content filtering security controls • a list of websites to which encrypted connections are allowed, with all other TLS traffic decrypted and inspected as per content filtering security controls.

control.title: Inspection of Transport Layer Security traffic

part.name: SecurityControl0996
part.p: Legal advice is sought regarding the inspection of TLS traffic by internet gateways.

part.name: SecurityControl0958
part.p: A list of allowed websites, using either domain name or IP address, is implemented for all Hypertext Transfer Protocol and Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure traffic communicated through internet gateways.

part.name: SecurityControl1170
part.p: If a list of allowed websites is not implemented, a list of allowed website categories is implemented instead.

part.name: SecurityControl0959
part.p: If a list of allowed websites is not implemented, a list of blocked websites is implemented instead.

part.name: SecurityControl0960
part.p: If a list of blocked websites is implemented, the list is updated on a daily basis to ensure that it remains effective.

part.name: SecurityControl1171
part.p: Attempts to access a website through its IP address instead of through its domain name are blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl1236
part.p: Dynamic domains and other domains where domain names can be registered anonymously for free are blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl0659
part.p: When importing data into a security domain, the data is filtered by a content filter designed for that purpose.

part.name: SecurityControl1524
part.p: Content filters deployed in a CDS are subject to rigorous security assessment to ensure they mitigate content-based threats and cannot be bypassed.

part.name: SecurityControl0651
part.p: All suspicious, malicious and active content is blocked from entering a security domain.

part.name: SecurityControl0652
part.p: Any data identified by a content filtering process as suspicious is blocked until reviewed and approved for transfer by a trusted source other than the originator.

part.name: SecurityControl1389
part.p: Email and web content entering a security domain is automatically run in a dynamic malware analysis sandbox to detect suspicious behaviour.

part.name: SecurityControl1284
part.p: Content validation is performed on all data passing through a content filter with content which fails content validation blocked.

part.name: SecurityControl1286
part.p: Content conversion is performed for all ingress or egress data transiting a security domain boundary.

part.name: SecurityControl1287
part.p: Content sanitisation is performed on suitable file types if content conversion is not appropriate for data transiting a security domain boundary.

part.name: SecurityControl1288
part.p: Antivirus scanning, using multiple different scanning engines, is performed on all content.

part.name: SecurityControl1289
part.p: The contents from archive/container files are extracted and subjected to content filter checks.

part.name: SecurityControl1290
part.p: Controlled inspection of archive/container files is performed to ensure that content filter performance or availability is not adversely affected.

part.name: SecurityControl1291
part.p: Files that cannot be inspected are blocked and generate an alert or notification.

control.title: Allowing access to specific content types

part.name: SecurityControl0649
part.p: A list of allowed content types is implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl1292
part.p: The integrity of content is verified where applicable and blocked if verification fails.

part.name: SecurityControl0677
part.p: If data is signed, the signature is validated before the data is exported.

part.name: SecurityControl1293
part.p: All encrypted content, traffic and data is decrypted and inspected to allow content filtering.

part.name: SecurityControl0591
part.p: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1457
part.p: An evaluated peripheral switch used for sharing peripherals between SECRET and TOP SECRET systems, or between SECRET or TOP SECRET systems belonging to different security domains, preferably completes a high assurance evaluation.

part.name: SecurityControl1480
part.p: An evaluated peripheral switch used for sharing peripherals between SECRET or TOP SECRET systems and any non-SECRET or TOP SECRET systems completes a high assurance evaluation.

part.name: SecurityControl0663
part.p: Data transfer processes, and supporting data transfer procedures, are developed and implemented.

part.name: SecurityControl0661
part.p: Users transferring data to and from a system are held accountable for the data they transfer.

part.name: SecurityControl0664
part.p: All data transferred from a SECRET or TOP SECRET system to any other system is reviewed and approved by a trusted source.

part.name: SecurityControl0675
part.p: A trusted source signs all data authorised for export from a SECRET or TOP SECRET system.

part.name: SecurityControl0665
part.p: Trusted sources for SECRET and TOP SECRET systems are limited to people and services that have been authorised as such by an organisation’s Chief Information Security Officer.

part.name: SecurityControl0657
part.p: Data imported to a system is scanned for malicious and active content.

part.name: SecurityControl0658
part.p: Data imported to a SECRET or TOP SECRET system undergoes data format checks and logging, and is monitored to detect overuse/unusual usage patterns.

part.name: SecurityControl1187
part.p: When exporting data from a system, protective marking checks are undertaken.

part.name: SecurityControl0669
part.p: When exporting data from a SECRET or TOP SECRET system, the following activities are undertaken: • data format checks and logging • monitoring to detect overuse/unusual usage patterns • limitations on data types and sizes • keyword searches on all textual data.

control.title: Preventing export of highly sensitive data to foreign systems

part.name: SecurityControl1535
part.p: Processes, and supporting procedures, are developed and implemented to prevent AUSTEO and AGAO data in both textual and non-textual formats from being exported to foreign systems.

control.title: Preventing export of highly sensitive data to foreign systems

part.name: SecurityControl0678
part.p: When exporting AUSTEO or AGAO data from a system, keyword searches are undertaken on all textual data and any identified data is quarantined until reviewed and approved for release by a trusted source other than the originator.

part.name: SecurityControl1586
part.p: Data transfer logs are used to record all data imports and exports from systems.

part.name: SecurityControl1294
part.p: Data transfer logs for systems are partially audited at least monthly.

part.name: SecurityControl0660
part.p: Data transfer logs for SECRET and TOP SECRET systems are fully audited at least monthly.
